Tribute to the Late Dr Toh Chin Chye

Mr Speaker : Order. On behalf of this House, allow me to pay tribute to the late Dr Toh Chin Chye. On behalf of the House, I would like to place on record the demise of Dr Toh Chin Chye, former Deputy Prime Minister, on 3 February 2012.

Dr Toh was first elected as a Member of the First Legislative Assembly for Rochor constituency on 30 May 1959. He retained his seat over six successive General Elections and eventually retired from this House on 16 August 1988. In a parliamentary career that spanned some 29 years, Dr Toh had served with distinction as a Cabinet Minister from 1959 to 1981, as Leader of the House from 1959 to 1968, and finally, as a backbench Member from 1981 to 1988. Shortly after winning the 1959 General Election, Dr Toh was appointed Singapore's first Deputy Prime Minister and continued in that office until 1968.

By the time Dr Toh stepped down from office in 1981, he had helmed a number of Ministries, serving as Minister for National Development, Minister for Science and Technology, Minister for Health, Minister for Education and Minister for Social Affairs. Dr Toh was a founding father of modern Singapore and had made significant contributions to Singapore's development during our crucial nation-building years. Dr Toh will be remembered for his great integrity, his tenacity and his unwavering determination to serve the cause of Singapore, his beloved country, to the best of his ability. Succeeding generations owe much to the dedication and toil of visionary leaders like Dr Toh, whose distinguished contributions to Singapore and to this House will always be remembered.

Page: 1084

On behalf of this House, I would like to express our deep sense of loss at the passing of Dr Toh Chin Chye. I join all Members in expressing our deep sympathy and condolences to the family of the late Dr Toh Chin Chye. As a mark of respect to the late Dr Toh Chin Chye, I propose that the House observe one minute of silence. Will Members please rise.

[The House rose and observed a one-minute silence.]

Oral Answers to Questions

Page: 1084

Occupancy Requirements under the Interim Rental Housing Scheme

1 Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim asked the Minister for National Development (a) how does HDB engage the residents under the Interim Rental Housing Scheme (IRH) to adjust to living with other families; and (b) whether there are plans to provide for housing under the IRH based on single-family occupancy rather than the current multiple-families occupancy.

The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to Minister for National Development (Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman) (for the Minister for National Development) : Mr Speaker, Sir, the main mode of HDB rental is based on single-family occupancy, in 1-room and 2-room public rental units. There are currently about 48,500 such rental units in operation.

The Interim Rental Housing (IRH) came about because there were a number of old HDB blocks which were vacated, pending demolition. To put them to some interim use, HDB decided to rent them out to families in financial hardship requiring urgent temporary accommodation. As IRH flats are 3-room or larger flats, co-sharing helps tenants reduce their rental cost. There are currently about 1,000 IRH rental units.

Understandably, co-sharing arrangement is not preferred. But it is manageable, provided the tenants exercise tolerance, consideration and respect. HDB plays an active role in pairing the families; it will take into account factors such as race, religion and family size. HDB will also proactively get the families to meet up, before they are paired. This should help to improve the chance of successful co-sharing.

Dr Lily Neo (Tanjong Pagar) : Mr Speaker, may I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether MND will do away with the Interim Rental Housing scheme in view of the various side-effects that this scheme brings, such as the social problems associated with it and the heavy rental burdens? Does the Senior Parliamentary Secretary not agree that these associated issues further jeopardise the dire predicaments that these residents were already facing? And will MND consider long-term solutions for this group of lowest income residents who have exhausted their public housing options due to previous circumstances or misfortunes, by giving them one extra last chance to purchase 3-room HDB flats, albeit with the stricter rules on subsequent resale by them?

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman : Sir, I thank the Member for the question. I understand the concerns on the ground. Many Members would have met some of these families. Let me just explain the profile of the families in the Interim Rental Housing (IRH) scheme. As mentioned earlier, IRH is a temporary measure to help families who are low-income and are looking for permanent accommodation. They do not have current accommodation. It is temporary. There are different groups of families in the IRH. There are families who are currently without housing options, and we try to use the IRH to give them stability first as we try and help them look for longer term housing options. There are those who are waiting for allocation of rental flats – meaning they have already been allocated a rental flat but are waiting for allocation. There are those who are waiting for BTO flats and because the BTO flats take some time to be ready and they do not have alternative accommodation and their families cannot accommodate them, we would then allow for them to stay in IRH. There are those who are really looking for other options.

Page: 1085

I think what the Member is asking is: how do we manage to help them cope with the co-sharing existence that the IRH offers. At this point in time, we recognise that there are some issues. HDB has put in new measures to try and minimise their discomfort. Most importantly is for us to try to see if local community support systems can be activated to help these families. Certainly, this is a temporary measure. As mentioned earlier, the IRH is not a permanent feature. It is something that we want to put in place to help families in transition. We hope to help these families transit into long-term accommodation.

Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (Nee Soon) : Sir, I would like to thank the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for the answer. While I understand this is a transition process, I find that it is important for us to provide basic housing for Singaporeans. I would like to appeal to the Ministry to consider how, as we ramp up the supply of rental flats, we can also provide single-occupancy for these families. As they transit, we want them to climb up the ladder again. We want them to succeed in life. We must provide adequate and sufficient housing facilities for them, so that they can live a better life as a family, and as part of the Singaporean family.

The other issue that I would like to seek clarification on is: how has HDB looked into the interests of the younger children in school? I visited a few of them and I saw young children. I am concerned as to how they are able to cope with school. It is important that their educational needs are not affected. It is important that we take care because this is our future generation.

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman : Sir, as mentioned in my reply earlier, indeed, the main bulk of rental housing for Singaporeans is the 1-room and 2-room rental flats. For the longer term 1-room and 2-room rental flats, they are provided for single families. They are not shared. For the IRH flats, they are shared because the IRH units are 3- and 4-room flats, and co-sharing is to reduce the rental cost for these families.

On the issue of how we try to help the families and the children: not all the families in IRH scheme require assistance. Some of them are able to cope. They are stable, earn sufficient income and are able to manage childcare arrangements. For the small group of families who really do need help, HDB works very closely with MCYS and the Family Service Centres. These families are referred to the Family Service Centres for them to receive social services to ensure that the needs of the children are not compromised and continued to be addressed, as highlighted by the hon Member.

Page: 1086

Ms Ellen Lee (Sembawang) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary: if an applicant who has been offered this interim housing has consistently requested not to share the flat because of special needs children in the family, would it result in the offer being taken away from his family permanently, in the sense that it will not be given because of the rejection to share with another family?

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman : Sir, HDB tries its best to pair the families as best it can. It looks at various factors and issues. But we certainly recognise that the circumstances may be different when it comes to children with special needs. For such circumstances, I would encourage the Member to let us know so that we can look into this case individually.

Dr Lily Neo : May I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary what he meant earlier when he said "temporary housing". I noticed that the majority of them have to stay more than one to two years and there was still no other option. May I also ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether it is fair to put two families who are strangers with 12 kids between them in a 2-room flat? How do we get these people to tolerate one another?

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman : Sir, what I meant was that IRH is not permanent housing. IRH is temporary housing. When a family needs accommodation, we try to help them with various options. One is, if they are really low-income and do not have any other options, we try to help them with rental flats if they have already exhausted many of the housing opportunities available to them. For public rental, we try very hard to accommodate and provide after we have assessed that the family is really in need of public rental flats.

As highlighted earlier, at this point in time, we are in short supply of public rental flats. My Minister has announced earlier that we are increasing the supply of public rental flats. We have done our best and have improved the duration it takes for families waiting for public rental flats. So what I meant by IRH being temporary is that they are moving towards longer term accommodation, whether it is public rental or to another flat. We do help families to downsize to a smaller flat. Some of the families who are waiting for the BTO flats are waiting for the smaller 2-room BTO flats. HDB helps them personally to acquire these smaller HDB flats.

We acknowledge that there are some situations where families with many children are put together. We have fine-tuned the process. HDB is taking greater oversight of the situation, trying to make sure that they pair families to minimise the situation where families with a greater number of children are paired together. Moving forward, with the new guidelines in place, we hope that the situation can be improved. In the longer term, we also want to ensure that the social support services from the Family Service Centres continue to be provided to these families while they are in this temporary housing accommodation.

Page: 1086

Unauthorised Subletting of HDB Flats

2 Mr Ang Hin Kee asked the Minister for National Development over the last three years (a) what is the number of cases of HDB flats found to be sublet without permission from HDB; and (b) how many of these cases involve HDB flats owned by Permanent Residents.

Page: 1087

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (for the Minister for National Development) : Mr Speaker, Sir, over the last three years, HDB has taken action against 179 flat owners for unauthorised subletting. Of these, eight flats were owned by Singapore Permanent Residents (PRs).

Mr Ang Hin Kee (Ang Mo Kio) : Sir, I thank the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for his reply. I would also like to thank the Ministry for the previous written replies on related matters. May I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary how investigations are conducted to ensure that the flats are not illegally sublet, and what penalties are imposed on those who do so illegally?

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman : Sir, all flat owners who wish to sublet their flats must obtain approval from HDB and fulfil the minimum occupation period. This subletting policy applies consistently to all flat owners – Singapore Citizens as well as Singapore PRs.

What are the measures that HDB has put in place against unauthorised subletting? There are several measures, and they include:

(i) requiring the flat owners to seek HDB's prior approval before subletting, as mentioned earlier, so that they do not get into trouble. Whether they are eligible or not, it is better for them to start by asking HDB for approval;

(ii) granting subletting approval to eligible cases for a maximum of three years, subject to subsequent extension or renewal, meaning that it is not automatic, so that people do not take for granted that once it is approved, they can go ahead and sublet it to anybody that they want to;

(iii) conducting half-yearly flat inspections of approved subletting cases by the Branch officers to detect any irregularities, for example, the number of sub-tenants, whether it exceeds the limit permissible;

(iv) conducting planned and routine inspections of flats to ensure proper occupation by the flat lessees; and

(v) engaging periodically grassroots organisations' assistance to provide feedback on irregularities.

The HDB provides a dedicated hotline for members of the public to provide feedback on unauthorised subletting of these flats. In fact, many times, we take action and investigate based on feedback from the residents living within the vicinity of the sublet flats. We also publicise the action taken against lessees who have committed unauthorised subletting of their flats or breached the subletting rules, to serve as a deterrent. On the penalties, HDB can and has compulsorily acquired flats which have been sublet without authorisation, or, in lieu of compulsory acquisition, we impose a fine.

Page: 1088

Investigations of Former Top Officers at Singapore Civil Defence Force and Central Narcotics Bureau

(Updates)

3 Mr Lim Biow Chuan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) why information about the arrests of senior Government servants were not made public until weeks later; and (b) whether the Government should have suspended senior civil servants from their official duties once they have been arrested.

4 Mr Edwin Tong Chun Fai asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) whether he can provide an update on the status of investigations into the cases involving the former Commissioner of the Singapore Civil Defence Force and former Director of the Central Narcotics Bureau; (b) why the arrests/investigations are not disclosed earlier; and (c) whether the investigations have revealed lapses in the agencies' procurement systems and processes and, if so, what will be done to address these lapses.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Teo Chee Hean) : Mr Speaker, Sir, may I take Question Nos 3 and 4 together, please?

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : Sir, Mr Lim Biow Chuan and Mr Edwin Tong have asked why the arrests of the former Commissioner of the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) and the former Director of the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) were not made known earlier. As was made known in a Ministry of Home Affairs' statement on 24 January 2012, the CPIB commenced interviewing Mr Ng Boon Gay on 19 December 2011 and Mr Peter Lim on 4 January 2012. In CPIB investigations, it is normal procedure for the person to be placed under arrest if CPIB assesses that there is some basis for suspecting that the person may have committed an offence. Both persons were placed under arrest. They were then released on bail to secure their attendance for further investigations as required.

At that point in time, it was premature to make any announcement as CPIB was in the midst of their investigations and the outcome was not known. It was necessary to give CPIB time to gather evidence, seize documents, conduct interviews with various persons who were connected to the case and establish whether further action was warranted. A public announcement at that point in time would have compromised the investigations. On the day that CPIB interviewed the two officers and decided to place them under arrest, the Ministry of Home Affairs placed each of the two officers on leave on the respective dates. They were told not to return to their offices, nor to carry out any official duties. Their deputies acted during their period of absence on leave. As investigations were still underway, it was also premature and not fair to remove the officers from their office or to interdict them from their duties then, until the situation became clearer.

An arrest by CPIB does not necessarily mean that the person would be prosecuted in court or referred for some disciplinary action, for example, civil service disciplinary action. It is possible that after referral to the Attorney General's Chambers, no further action is taken. So an arrest, therefore, has no bearing on the guilt or innocence of a person.

Page: 1089

On Friday, 20 January 2012, CPIB informed the Ministry of Home Affairs that although their criminal investigations have not been completed, there was sufficient basis for the Ministry to consider civil service disciplinary action for misconduct. The Ministry of Home Affairs immediately commenced civil service disciplinary proceedings, including interdicting the officers from their duties. On 24 January 2012, after obtaining the Public Service Commission's approval, the Ministry of Home Affairs called up the two officers and served them notices of interdiction, which took effect from 25 January 2012. The Ministry of Home Affairs had intended to carry out these procedures on 25 January 2012, which was the first working day after the four-day weekend and Chinese New Year holiday, and make a media statement on that same day. We received the notification from the CPIB on the Friday before that weekend. However, as one newspaper had reported the matter on the morning of 24 January, the Ministry of Home Affairs decided to advance the process and media release by one day to 24 January 2012, which was the second day of Chinese New Year.

There was thus no delay in the release of information. Due process in both the investigations and disciplinary proceedings had to be followed to avoid prejudicing any subsequent legal or civil service disciplinary proceedings, as well as to be fair to the officers accused. A premature release of information in such cases would jeopardise the investigations, and also unfairly prejudice the officers and any other parties who are involved in the case.

CPIB investigations are still on-going. Once the outcome of the investigations is known, the MHA will correct any lapses uncovered in the procurement systems and processes in the Singapore Civil Defence Force and the Central Narcotics Bureau. The civil service and MHA will apply those same lessons civil service-wide where applicable. In the meantime, MHA has reviewed various outstanding IT tenders, including the composition of the tender evaluation committees. This has been done to safeguard the integrity and fairness of the tender system.

Sir, it is disappointing that these cases have occurred. However, as both cases have shown, any allegation of misconduct against public officers is investigated fully, regardless of the position or seniority of the officers involved. This Government will continue to require the highest standards of integrity and conduct in the public service. The public depends on the Home Team officers to do their job right, and to do it properly. The key to this is that they act with the utmost integrity in whatever they do. MHA will do its utmost to uphold the trust which has been placed in our officers.

Mr Edwin Tong Chun Fai (Moulmein-Kallang) : Sir, I thank the Deputy Prime Minister for the answers to the questions. May I ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he thinks that the two CPIB investigations and the recent probes into allegations of vice activities involving public servants reflect the lowering of the moral and ethical standards to which members of our public service are held?

Mr Teo Chee Hean : Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government is committed to upholding high moral and ethical standards in the public service. And I have confidence that the vast majority of civil servants do live up to these standards. However, when we come across an officer who has transgressed, we will not hesitate to act against him, even if he is in a senior position and even if it may embarrass the Government. I have told our public officers to continue to hold true to the public service values of integrity, excellence and service, and to continue to carry out their duties diligently, honestly and to the best of their abilities. And this is the way that they would be able to maintain the public's high trust in the public service and our officers.

Page: 1090

Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Chua Chu Kang) : I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister, apart from the two officers, has any initial investigation shown that there is potential corruption by other officers in the service as a result of this. The second question is this: I do agree with the Deputy Prime Minister that the premature release of news would have jeopardised investigations. But the fact is that the media actually received news even before the official statement. Will MHA also investigate this leak to the media?

Mr Teo Chee Hean : We will investigate leaks to the media, particularly if official information which should not have been revealed was revealed. And I am not able to comment now on the further investigations of the CPIB and whether others are involved because investigations are still in progress.

Mr Lim Biow Chuan (Mountbatten) : Sir, I thank the Deputy Prime Minister for the reply. The public understand that arrests once made are not taken lightly. Bearing in mind the responsibility of the two persons concerned, the fact that they are Heads of respective departments, what is the possibility that had they remained unsuspended in their positions that they would be able to influence the outcome of the investigations? Perhaps, the Deputy Prime Minister could clarify that so that there would not be any kind of doubt that they can remain in their positions so that they can influence the outcome of the investigations.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : There should be no doubt that the officers were removed from positions of responsibility and any ability to influence the outcome of investigations the moment the investigations began by CPIB. When the CPIB decided that they should be placed under arrest, they were placed on leave from their duties. Therefore, they were not able to continue with their duties and they were told not to come back to office, not to exercise their official duties. And when CPIB informed the Ministry of Home Affairs that there was sufficient basis to consider commencing civil service disciplinary proceedings, we then took steps to interdict them. So there is clearly no ability for them to have influenced the proceedings of the investigations due to their positions in office.

Channels for Reporting Improper Conduct of Senior Officers in Uniformed Services

5 Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) what channels are available for uniformed officers to furnish information about improper conduct of superior officers; (b) how many times have these channels been used in the last five years against superiors, what was the nature of the information given and what was the outcome of such reporting; (c) what repercussions will an officer face for giving information about a superior which is not substantiated or proven; and (d) whether reporting of superiors is hampered by the strict hierarchy of ranks within the uniformed services.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : Sir, Ms Lim asked about the channels available for uniformed officers to report improper conduct of superior officers. The Home Team has a reporting framework in place, which provides a confidential channel for officers to report any wrongful behaviour of officers. Under this reporting framework, the usual channel for a uniformed MHA officer to raise concerns and feedback is to do so in person, or in writing, to designated persons within the officer's Home Team Department. The designated persons in the Home Team Departments are typically the Head of Department or the Deputy Head of Department. If, however, officers prefer to raise their concerns to a channel outside their Department, they can furnish the information to the Deputy Secretary or the Senior Director, Human Resource in the Ministry Headquarters. The identity of the reporting officer will be kept confidential.

Page: 1091

Sir, this approach ensures that the reporting of any instance of improper conduct of a superior officer is not hampered by the hierarchy of ranks within the uniformed services. The above confidential reporting framework is communicated to our officers, and is contained in the Code of Conduct guide book issued to every officer [indicating]. This is the Home Team Code of Conduct guide book and the channel for confidential ethical disclosure is there for all of them to see, on page 5 of this guide book.

The key principle of our reporting policy is that reports should be made in good faith. If a report is made in good faith, but a case of wrongdoing cannot be established after investigation, no action will be taken against the reporting officer. If, however, an allegation is made frivolously, maliciously or proven to be falsified, disciplinary action may be taken against the officer. This is also explained in the Code of Conduct guide book.

In the last five years, there were 59 cases reported; 44 of these cases were anonymous, so we are unable to ascertain if they were from subordinates or from peers. Of the 15 which were not anonymous, eight were against a superior officer. Wrongful practices reported include allegations of failure to comply with procedures, and improper conduct or unethical behaviour. After investigation, errant officers will be dealt with in accordance with established disciplinary procedures.

We expect our officers to report a wrongdoing if they have sufficient grounds to believe that it has been committed, even if the report is against a superior officer, even if it is his direct superior officer, and the channels in the reporting framework for this are in place. This framework ensures that the highest standards of conduct will be upheld in the organisation.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : I do not have the findings of the CPIB report of the investigations. Anonymity, of course, is something which we do not encourage, because we encourage officers to identify themselves so that it is possible to seek their assistance when we look into the cases that are brought up. But where there are anonymous reports, we will still look into them if the reports have substance and if they are serious. But if it is a frivolous, anonymous report with no basis, no substance, very few details, then of course it is not possible to investigate the report. Maintaining Integrity in the Public Service

6 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Prime Minister what measures has the Government taken to maintain the integrity and incorruptibility of the public service.

7 Mr Pritam Singh asked the Prime Minister in light of investigations into senior SCDF and CNB officers (a) whether the Government will conduct a comprehensive review of the feedback mechanisms currently in place in the civil service; and (b) whether the Government will consider whistleblower/whistleblower protection legislation and the institution of a national ombudsman to act as layers of deterrence against wayward civil servants.

Mr Teo Chee Hean (for the Prime Minister) : Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, may I take Question Nos 6 and 7 together?

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : Sir, the civil service is governed by a Code of Conduct based on the principles of integrity, incorruptibility and impartiality. The Code articulates key conduct principles and expected behaviour of our officers. All officers are expected to maintain a high standard of conduct by upholding the integrity of the public service and public confidence in it. We do not tolerate corruption, which is an abuse of position and trust.

There are specific requirements set out in this Code. For example, where decisions are taken on issues which an officer is deemed to have personal interest in, he must declare his interest. Officers should not accept gifts on account of their official position. Where it is impractical or inappropriate to refuse, the gift must be declared.

The Ministry of Finance (MOF) sets out the Government financial procedures and procurement rules, and reviews these on a regular basis. Ministries are required to put in place sound accounting practices and internal controls to ensure integrity of their financial systems. These include the rotation of officers handling financial work and segregation of duties so that no single officer is allowed to handle all phases of a transaction. For instance, in procuring goods and services, the officer who approves the award of contracts or quotations is different from the officer who approves payments. For procurement tenders, the approving authority for award consists of a panel of at least three officers, rather than an individual.

Page: 1093

Internal audits are also conducted on a regular basis. In addition, there is scrutiny by the Auditor-General's Office (AGO) and Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee which examines various accounts of the Government. While the principles, policies and processes are in place, the leaders must set the tone for effective implementation. We expect Public Service Leaders to have the ability, commitment and integrity to act in the national interest. They are selected and assessed on that basis. Where they fail to meet the high standards expected, appropriate corrective action will be taken.

To reinforce high standards of conduct and accountability, there is a reporting framework for officers to report wrongful practices or behaviour they have observed in the service. Officers should be vigilant and make a report if they have sufficient grounds to believe a wrongdoing has been committed. There are multiple avenues for officers to report wrongdoings and irregularities. Apart from making such reports internally within their own departments or agencies, officers can escalate cases of misconduct to their Permanent Secretary of the Ministry or the Head of Civil Service. In addition, they can also report wrongdoing to the Public Service Commission (PSC), which is an independent body, set up under the Singapore Constitution, vested with the authority to exercise disciplinary control over civil servants. Corruption cases may be raised with CPIB. Where there is sufficient basis and information provided, the complaints will be looked into.

CPIB plays a pivotal role in curbing corruption. CPIB acts swiftly against offenders who, if convicted of corruption offences, face severe penalties. As part of CPIB's preventive programmes, it regularly reaches out to Government agencies to remind officers of the importance of maintaining incorruptibility and the potential consequences of failure to do so. CPIB also reviews the work processes and procedures of Government departments to see whether there are systemic flaws which can be exploited. In cases where corruption is not involved, but the law has been broken, for example, where public funds or property have been stolen or misappropriated, the matter will be investigated by the Police. The officer can be charged under appropriate provisions in the law according to the facts of the case.

Even when there are insufficient grounds to proceed against an officer under the law, there may be sufficient grounds to proceed with civil service disciplinary proceedings against an officer for misconduct. In such cases, the Public Service Commission will institute formal disciplinary proceedings against the officer. An officer who has been found to have mis-conducted himself could be reprimanded, fined or have his increment forfeited, reduced in rank, retired in the public interest or dismissed depending on the severity of the issue. If an officer is found to be responsible for loss of public money or Government property, the officer involved may also be required to make good the losses.

All reporting will be treated with utmost confidentiality and every effort will be made not to reveal the identity of the officer, to the extent feasible and permissible under law. If an officer has sufficient grounds to feel that he is being treated unfairly as a result of a report that he has made, he may submit a complaint to his Permanent Secretary. Therefore, there are already provisions for the protection of officers who make such reports. I should add that we should encourage responsible reporting and discourage malicious or frivolous allegations. Those who make reports are expected to identify themselves. If a report is made in bad faith or for personal gain, disciplinary action may be taken against the officer making the false report.

Page: 1094

The measures I have outlined guide our officers on proper conduct, deter the officers from misconduct and reduce the opportunity for corruption and wrongdoing. However, even in the best of systems, no one can guarantee that corruption or wrongdoing can be entirely eradicated and that there will never be cases of misconduct, as there will always be human failings, human weaknesses which we may discover later. To sum up, there are multiple channels for raising irregularities. Independent bodies like the Public Service Commission (PSC), the Auditor-General's Office (AGO) and CPIB are involved in the process.

The recent cases demonstrate that there are strict rules, reporting procedures, and legal and disciplinary processes in place to maintain the integrity of the public service and the proper conduct of public officers. This Government is committed to upholding high moral and ethical standards in the public service.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : Indeed, Mr Speaker, I said at the outset of my reply, the very first sentence, that the civil service is governed by a Code of Conduct in the Instruction Manuals. So, there are such written Codes of Conduct.

Ms Tin Pei Ling (Marine Parade) : I thank the Deputy Prime Minister for a very comprehensive reply. May I just seek the confirmation and assurance from the Deputy Prime Minister that integrity is the key criterion in terms of selecting our officers at the recruitment process as well as in terms of promotion?

Mr Teo Chee Hean : Certainly, I can assure the Member that integrity, ability, commitment to the service and to serving Singaporeans are key attributes which we look for at recruitment and appointment, and in our continual assessment of our officers. But as Members will know, the assessment of an individual is a very difficult thing. A person whom you may know for five years, or 10 years, may have some weaknesses which are only uncovered later, or which may develop later. The important thing in such cases is to be clear, accountable and transparent. And how an organisation responds to such things defines the organisation. This Government has always been clear and unequivocal in dealing with any such issues of integrity, honesty or wrongdoing. We come out with it in the open, we deal with it by the law or by disciplinary proceedings, and we are not shy of doing so even if it causes embarrassment to the Government.

Safety of Students on Roads

9 Dr Intan Azura Mokhtar asked the Minister for Education what measures are taken by the Ministry to ensure that Primary schools attend to the safety of its students especially on roads next to the schools which are accessed by many students before and after school hours.

The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Minister for Education) : Sir, there are several measures in place to enhance road safety around our schools. In consultation with the Ministry of Education (MOE), the Land Transport Authority (LTA) introduced the Enhanced School Zone (ESZ) scheme in 2005 at Primary schools to increase the visibility of school zones. Parts of the road surface near the school gate are covered with a red textured surface to capture drivers' attention and to alert them to look out for children crossing the roads. There are also bigger traffic signs with yellow backing to indicate the start and end of school zones.

Page: 1097

Since 2009, for all new Primary schools and schools undergoing major upgrading works, MOE works with LTA to conduct a Traffic Impact Assessment to develop optimal traffic arrangements within and around the school. In addition, MOE provides schools with a handbook to support them in ensuring safety within and in the vicinity of the school as well as to provide road safety education.

Schools teach our students important personal habits and road safety behaviour. School leaders highlight road safety habits during assembly at the beginning of the year, and students are reminded again of the importance of road safety during the course of the year. For Primary schools, road safety is also a topic in the Health Education syllabus at the lower primary levels.

During peak periods such as arrival and dismissal, Primary schools deploy staff, security guards or parent volunteers at school gates to reinforce road safety behaviour.

The safety of students using roads around the school is the responsibility of all. We need motorists to play their part by slowing down in the vicinity of schools, and parents to reinforce the importance of road safety at home.

That is a very important aspect. Schools also work with parent volunteers in getting support to help ensure that the students can use the roads safely during peak hours, during arrival as well as dismissal times. Schools also work very closely with the community organisations around the school to get their support to educate members of the public. Regulation of Fundraising Activities

13 Mr Sitoh Yih Pin asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth, Sports what is the regulatory policy towards fundraising activities such as the recent "Elephant Parade"; (b) whether such sales of products are allowed to be positioned as a charity fundraising event; and (c) whether the regulations will be tightened to protect the interests of the local charities and potential donors.

The Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mr Chan Chun Sing) : Mr Speaker, Sir, any appeal to raise funds in Singapore where the entire or part of the proceeds is for charitable purposes is regulated under the Charities Act. If the organisers are raising funds for overseas charitable causes, they would have to apply for a permit from the Office of the Commissioner of Charities and comply with a set of conditions. These include providing clear information to donors on the fund-raising purpose and the intended beneficiaries and submitting audited accounts after the fund-raising event.

The recent "Elephant Parade" was an initiative by a commercial company to raise public awareness and support for elephant conservation projects in Asia. The organiser sought sponsorship for the production of life-size elephant statues, arranged for them to be painted by artists and well-known personalities, and exhibited them at various parts of Singapore for two months. These elephants were then sold at a private auction opened only to invited guests. This event has been held in other cities such as London, Milan and Amsterdam since 2006. "Elephant Parade Singapore" is not a pure charity fundraising event where the bulk of the proceeds go to charities. It is a sale of merchandise by a commercial company, where part of the proceeds is donated to charities and the remaining parts used to cover cost or retained as profits. In this case, 20% of the auction proceeds were donated to an overseas charity and another 5% to a local charity.

As required by the Office of the Commissioner of Charities, the organiser had to provide accurate information to potential customers and disclose how the monies raised would be used. They were not allowed to give the impression that the event was a charity fundraising where the whole or majority of the proceeds goes to the charities. They also had to announce the allocation of the auction proceeds before the commencement of the auction.

While "Elephant Parade Singapore" had met these conditions, some invited guests and members of the public have given feedback that they were under the impression that the event was a charity fundraising where the majority of the proceeds would go to the charities. Some commented that they had formed this impression because of the display of the painted elephant statues in publicly-accessible places, as well as the media coverage on the statues.

Such fundraising arrangements by commercial companies are becoming more common. While we would encourage corporate social responsibility and the giving spirit among companies, we also need to protect public and donor interest.

Bed occupancy rates for HDs and ICUs vary across different hospitals and time periods. The bed occupancy rate in 2011, up to the end of the third quarter of 2011, for HD was 60% while the bed occupancy rate for ICU was 73.1%.

We recognise that the demand for such facilities would increase as our population ages with increasing prevalence of chronic diseases coupled with advances in medical treatment that enable treatment of increasingly more complex cases. We would thus be increasing the number of high dependency and intensive care beds even as we increase the overall number of public hospital beds. At the same time, we need to use these facilities appropriately and ensure right siting so that only patients who need HD and ICU beds are warded in such facilities.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Ong has raised a very important point. What is more important as we progress is that we must recognise that as our population ages, we will see an increasing prevalence of chronic diseases, as Mr Ong has pointed out. But if we do nothing, these diseases will progress and we will end up with many of the patients developing multiple morbidities, and many of them will end up in hospitals and putting a stress on our hospital system as well as our healthcare system overall. But to address this problem, while we continue to add hospital beds, we must also look at how we can manage these chronic diseases better and more effectively.

It is for this reason that we have introduced recently the Primary Care Master Plan. Through this Master Plan, we hope to be able to transform the primary care sector to deliver patient-centric, team-based, holistic care to manage the chronic diseases more cost-effectively. At the same time, we have also enhanced our Primary Care Partnership Scheme, or what we now call Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS). Through this scheme, we tap on the capacity in the private sector (the private GPs) to help us manage the chronic diseases in the community so that we can prevent these diseases from progressing into multiple morbidities. And we hope that through this Primary Care Master Plan as well as CHAS, we will be able to be more effective in managing these diseases and reduce the load on the hospital beds. This will be beneficial to the society as a whole and, more importantly, this will be beneficial to the patients themselves. I hope to be able to share more with Members during the COS.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : Mr Speaker, as I mentioned earlier, we would like to share more details during the COS. But more than just building beds, we also have to look at various measures to manage the demand in the hospitals. For example, right siting is very important. We want to make sure that only those who need to be hospitalised will be hospitalised. Patients who can be cared for in community hospitals, in nursing homes or even at home, we should find ways to encourage them and facilitate better care in the community as well as at home.

These are the various measures that we will be discussing during the COS. In the short term, while we build more capacity in the hospitals, the various healthcare institutions also look at measures to increase effective capacity. One example is to shorten the length of stay. If we are able to shorten the length of stay, manage it better, then, effectively, you create more bed space for patients.

Secondly, we are also looking at whether we can decant some of the administrative facilities or spaces to convert them into medical facilities that can provide additional space. We are also looking at how we can manage the process more efficiently, such as discharge processes, so that it is more efficient for us to discharge patients when they are ready rather than to have to wait for administrative procedures to be completed. And if we are able to discharge patients more efficiently, then we will also be able to create more space to cater for the increasing needs.

Legal Profession (Amendment) Bill

Order for Second Reading read.

3.02 pm

The Minister for Law (Mr K Shanmugam) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time." Sir, the Bill makes three key amendments to the Legal Profession Act, to strengthen the legal industry in Singapore. Let me explain the changes.

The first of these changes makes it slightly easier for foreign expert counsel to appear in our Courts. The policy on the admission of foreign counsels to appear in our courts has evolved over time. Prior to1991, more QCs appeared in our courts. Many of us benefited from working with them, watching them in action, and pitting ourselves against them in Court. As our Bar developed, the conditions for admitting QCs were tightened. In 1991, admission was restricted to cases which were, in the view of the Court, of "sufficient" complexity and difficulty. In 1997, the first batch of Senior Counsel was appointed. Over the years, the Courts have gradually restricted ad hoc admissions of QC. This was in line with the 1991 Amendments. Meanwhile, Singapore has grown exponentially as a business and financial centre with a corresponding growth in the demand for top-tier legal representation. This has thrown up a different set of challenges. One of the key challenges has been that in several cases, litigants had difficulties getting a Senior Counsel (SC) in Singapore of their choice when they are up against a bank or a large corporate.

We have several SCs. The majority of them practise in large firms. These firms have extensive corporate practices serving a wide range of clients. As a result, many of our SCs from the big law firms often find themselves unable or unwilling to act for a client when a large bank or corporate is on the other side. The larger firms would have had some relationship with such banks and corporates. Thus, even if the bank or corporate does not instruct them in the specific case in question, the SCs will decline to accept instructions from the other side. The Courts have observed this to be quite a serious problem over the years. When he opened the Legal Year in 2010, the Chief Justice (CJ) said:

"€¦ there is another area of practice we might want to revisit – litigation, and the availability of top counsels to appear in our courts. Currently, we have a provision in the Legal Profession Act for the ad hoc admission of Queen's Counsel and Senior Counsel from other Commonwealth jurisdictions, in cases where legal expertise is not available. Fortunately, it is rare that we cannot find the necessary expertise since we have built up a pool of first class litigation counsel under our Senior Counsel scheme. However, many of them are no longer in active practice and not many appear frequently in our Courts, especially the Court of Appeal. In Opening of Legal Year 2002, I spoke on this topic and pointed out that a major corporate client with a court case could immobilise all the litigators in the large law firms, including our best Senior Counsel. [This is a point that the Chief Justice when he was Attorney-General thought about 10 years ago.] To maintain our eminence as an international business and financial centre, we should make available to litigants in important commercial and financial disputes a greater diversity of legal representation in our courts. I have discussed this with the Minister for Law. He agrees with me that this is an issue that needs looking into, and he intends to consult the Law Society on it."

Page: 1107

The CJ was very clear in what he has said and he did speak with me on several occasions on this matter. The CJ reiterated his point during the Opening of the Legal Year in 2011. Again I quote:

"This year will see the revival of the Singapore Circuit – not the Singapore Grand Prix – but something older which was sidelined by the need to grow our own pool of expert advocates. We now have a sizeable pool of Senior Counsel who provides advisory, arbitral and litigation services to offshore and onshore clients. However, experience has shown that their services may not be available to the general public in times of need. We have a very large financial and business sector in terms of contributions to our GDP – it grew from 24.4% out of a nominal GDP of S$158.1 billion in 2002 to 25.9% out of a nominal GDP of S$303.7 billion in 2010. But, the legal services provided to these sectors are dominated by a small number of large law firms. The result is that the best litigation counsel are usually conflicted out of advising or acting for claimants against big business as they are mainly concentrated in the large firms. So we need a greater diversity of expert counsel to advise, negotiate and pursue legitimate claims in court. This is not a new problem. The Ministry of Law has consulted the Law Society and the Senior Counsel Forum on the best way forward. We can expect amending legislation to be enacted this year. The Bar can rest assured that this will not be a free for all. The courts will admit ad hoc expert counsel on the basis of need, and not simply because a litigant can afford to pay. We do not want to disadvantage litigants who cannot afford equivalent representation, nor do we want to impede the nurturing of our own Senior Counsel. So, ad hoc admission will be on a case-by-case basis, with the court doing a judicious balancing of competing interests in each case."

Sir, clause 4 amends section 15 to deal with this situation. The amendments were made after frank and intensive consultations with the Law Society, the Forum of Senior Counsel and the Bar at large. The Bar was generally supportive of this proposal. Lawyers from mid-sized and small firms, in particular, were very supportive. There can now be a less restrictive approach to the ad hoc admission of QCs and foreign counsel holding appointments of equivalent distinction to QCs. Greater discretion will be given to the Courts. Nevertheless, the Chief Justice has stated during his address during the Opening of the Legal Year in 2012: that ad hoc counsel will only be admitted on the basis of need, and it will not be a free for all. The CJ will, before the amendments come into force, gazette the matters that the Court may consider in deciding whether to admit foreign counsel, and the Amendments give him the power to do so. There will remain prescribed areas of law, where ad hoc admissions need to be justified by special reasons. These are: constitutional and administrative law; criminal law; and family law areas.

The next key amendment relates to Singapore law practices. Sir, the legal services market today is a globalised one and increasingly competitive. Size, international presence and economies of scale matter. Consolidation is the trend. The international market is dominated by a handful of large international practices which secure the most lucrative transactional work. Singapore law practices realise this, and many of them are moving to embrace the new paradigm.

Page: 1108

To this end, my Ministry has been in consultation with the Law Society and a diverse range of Singapore law practices on the regulatory framework that will be needed for us. The thrust of the feedback that we have received is that Singapore law practices need more flexibility to collaborate with foreign law practices. One area which has been raised is the sharing of profits and the holding of shares in Singapore law firms by foreign entities. Currently, foreign lawyers can take profit or equity shares in Singapore law practices up to a maximum of 25%. Clause 10 amends section 130L, to clarify that foreign law practices may participate in such equity and profit sharing. At the same time, we will change our policies and rules to give greater flexibility to Singapore firms on how they collaborate with foreign law practices. Some of these changes are:

(i) Singapore law firms will be allowed to give an increased share of profit and equity in their practices to foreign lawyers, up from the current 25%;

(ii) When there is collaboration between a Singapore and foreign law practice, a lawyer will be allowed to be a partner in both practices;

(iii) A significantly greater degree of collaboration within Formal Law Alliances will be allowed;

(iv) Qualifying Foreign Law Practices (QFLPs) will be allowed to enter into Formal Law Alliances as well as Joint Law Ventures with Singapore law practices while retaining their QFLP licences.

There will be conditions imposed to ensure that the Singapore law practice remains in effective control of Singapore lawyers. Within these limits, we will allow Singapore law practices significant freedom and flexibility to tie up with foreign partners. The details of these changes will be put up on the Ministry of Law website after my speech.

I had earlier asked the Attorney-General to chair a Committee to undertake a comprehensive review of the framework regulating lawyers and law firms. The review will also put in place a systematic and clear framework for the future. We are also giving Singapore law practices more flexibility to expand their practices. First, Singapore law practices will be allowed to set up a related law corporation. That will give them more flexibility to structure their operations. They can also take advantage of corporate tax incentives. Second, Singapore lawyers will be able to hold executive appointments in companies set up by the Singapore law practice for related activities, such as patent agent services.

The third key area concerns mandatory continuing professional development. Last year, the Singapore Institute of Legal Education was set up. It was set up to administer legal education in Singapore. One of the Institute's functions is to oversee mandatory continuing professional development for the legal profession and that will be implemented later this year. Clauses 2, 5, 8(a) and (b) amend the Act to provide for the means to enforce mandatory continuing professional development obligations. The annual application by a lawyer for practising certificate will now need to be accompanied by a declaration in writing on matters to be prescribed by the Institute. This will include a statement that the applicant has fulfilled his continuing professional development obligations. If a lawyer fails to fulfil these obligations, the Institute can refer the case to the Law Society for disciplinary action.

Page: 1109

The remaining clauses make ancillary, consequential minor amendments to the Act. Sir, I beg to move.

3.14 pm

Mr Hri Kumar Nair (Bishan-Toa Payoh) : I declare my interest as a lawyer and a Senior Counsel. I will deal with the proposed amendments on the admission of foreign advocates and to allow a foreign law practice to become a shareholder in any Singapore law practice which is a law corporation or to share in the profits of any Singapore law practice. These amendments, like all Government policies, are born out of good intentions. However, the success of a policy is not determined by its intentions, but by its implementation and effect.

At the heart of the amendments is the desire to grow and add diversity to the legal market, and to give individuals and corporations greater freedom of choice. That is a good thing. However, free-market economics, while important, is not the only principle which should apply to the legal profession. In fact, hardly any country around the world, including those which practise free market economics, is completely free when it comes to legal services.

Let me touch on some relevant considerations. First, on foreign advocates. Not too many years ago, Queen's Counsels (QCs) were easily and readily admitted to argue cases in Singapore – that is, if you could afford one. The fact of the matter is that if one side appointed a QC, the other would inevitably ask for one as well – even if local Counsel were competent to handle the case. The result was that the larger, more complex cases were argued by QCs. All this was to the detriment of the local bar because it inhibited its development.

So we changed the rules. In 1991, the LPA was amended such that foreign advocates would only be admitted where the court is satisfied that a case is of sufficient difficulty and complexity and the circumstances of the case warrant his appointment. We also put in place a system of appointing our own QCs, or Senior Counsels. In 1992, the High Court had occasion to consider this change. Justice Chan Sek Keong, as he then was, noted that it intended to lay the foundation for the development of a strong local Bar by the imposition of more stringent conditions for the admission of QCs, but at the same time, to continue to allow litigants to avail of their services in appropriate cases, in cases where it is sufficiently complex and difficult. Ten years on, the High Court, in another case, commented that after nearly a decade following the change, it was fair to say that the local Bar had matured and was acquitting itself commendably. The Court also noted that there had been forged and carefully nurtured, particularly over those 10 years, a body of Senior Counsels, potential Senior Counsels and an impressive group of young advocates and solicitors, both in the public service and in the private sector, with excellent academic credentials and the right attitude.

A further 10 years on, our legal industry has stepped up further in quality and competency. To date, 68 Senior Counsels have been appointed, most of them from the private sector. Our local law firms have demonstrated that they are more than able to handle complex, high-value disputes. In the arbitration circuit where one crosses swords with law firms worldwide, our local firms have proved more than a match for others. The practice of law also attracts the best young minds in the country, and there remains a good pipeline of hungry, bright and impressive young advocates. What they need most is the experience and opportunities to allow them to become good advocates, as Horace Rumpole puts it, to stand on their hind legs and make an argument. That is because, where litigation is concerned, there is no substitute for arguing a case yourself. A large part of becoming a good counsel is from first-hand experience, dealing with complex issues, making tactical and strategic decisions, many times while on your feet.

Page: 1110

The proposed amendments may undermine all that has been achieved. First, it is unclear what the criteria for admission will be. The Minister says it will be slightly easier to admit foreign advocates. It is unclear what "slightly easier" means. The Honourable Chief Justice will now have the responsibility to specify the matters that the court may consider when deciding whether to admit a foreign lawyer. I am not against giving the Courts more discretion but it is the duty of the House, I feel, to make clear what policy considerations should dictate the exercise of that discretion as it is done under the current regime. Second, while the discretion is wider, the undisputed aim and the effect of the change is to make it easier for foreign advocates to be admitted to argue Singapore cases. It is a reversal of the earlier position. If this is the case, the question arises as to the need for this change, and who it is intended to benefit. Now I would like to make two points.

First, I am concerned that if we relax the criteria for ad hoc admission, we might end up going back to the old days of having many foreign advocates walking the hallways of our Courts, and stifling the development of our local talent. I accept that there may be areas where we lack expertise. But the LPA already allows for ad hoc admission in such cases.

It has been suggested that some litigants find it difficult to appoint local Senior Counsel, particularly when up against a large institution. Such institutions have on their panels the larger law firms and a good number of Senior Counsels is therefore unable or sometimes unwilling to act against them. I accept that happens in practice. I am not sure, however, whether this criticism is entirely sound as there are a number of Senior Counsels who do not practise in large firms. And it is unclear whether the litigant has made reasonable efforts to engage them. However, in cases where the litigant cannot secure a Senior Counsel, then I agree that he should be given more leeway to apply to admit a foreign advocate to argue his case for him.

However, the existing admission requirements can then be modified to allow for admission of foreign advocates in such cases. What I question is whether we need to make such wholesale and drastic changes to deal with that special case. Can we not tweet the current regime as opposed to having one which makes the criteria less clear and more ambiguous?

Parliament struck a balance in 1991 which it felt was appropriate. It allowed our local firms and legal industry to grow, while at the same time ensuring that in areas where we lacked the experience and knowledge, we could import that expertise. The formula has worked and I hope that the balance will continue to be struck under the proposed new regime. Can I ask the Minister to tell the House what considerations will now apply to the admission of foreign advocates? I understand that the Chief Justice will be presenting the considerations but could the Minister tell the House what consideration is being considered before that change is put into effect? More importantly, does the Minister have any concern that the development of the local Bar would be adversely affected and, if so, are there any plans to address this?

Page: 1111

Mr Speaker, on the second amendment of share ownership or profit sharing, the proposed amendments would also allow, for the first time, a foreign law practice to own shares in a Singapore law practice. The foreign law practice would have to comply with conditions which would be prescribed as well as conditions the Attorney-General may think fit to impose in such cases.

We have incrementally allowed foreign law firms to enter our legal industry. We have the Joint Law Venture licence, the Formal Law Alliance licence, the Qualifying Foreign Law Practice licence, the licensed foreign law practice licence and finally the representative office licence. There is no doubt that foreign firms have a role to play in our legal industry, and their presence enhances Singapore's position as an international hub for businesses. By setting up shop in Singapore, the firms provide expertise that may be lacking, increase the breadth of choices for clients and even provide good jobs for Singaporean lawyers. All these are good things.

This new move, however, suggests that the Government believes that the current framework is lacking in some respects. Allowing foreign law firms to hold an equity stake in a local law practice represents a change in the development of our legal landscape, and I think we should be careful as we go down this road. I am concerned about allowing a foreign law practice to own, and more importantly, dictate how a Singapore law practice functions. We must never forget the legal profession is a noble one. A lawyer serves his client but he owes a higher duty to the Court and to society. This requires sensitivity to local conditions and circumstances. By allowing a foreign legal practice to own part of a law firm, there is a serious risk that, with their financial muscle, they will now call the shots from abroad and dictate how the local firm should be run.

This problem was highlighted by one Mr Lindsay Esler, Operations, Managements and Projects Partner of an indigenous Hong Kong firm, who highlighted in an article that promotion decisions in the branch offices of international firms are generally made by the home office. The partners in the home office might have drastically different ideas regarding promotion criteria, and local lawyers would have to bend to the will of their foreign bosses if they wish to be promoted. It is also not uncommon to hear of glass ceilings for local lawyers when it comes to promotions. Furthermore, in a firm where the final decision lies abroad, the bottom line becomes paramount. Obtaining maximum financial returns might not necessarily coincide with what is best for the legal industry and, more importantly, what is best for society. In April 2004, for example, Denton Wilde Sapte axed its entire Asian network and, in January 2012, CMS Cameron McKenna laid off 69 of its 75 staff in Hong Kong. Here at home, when the financial crisis hit in 2009, The Business Times reported that foreign law firms in Singapore started trimming headcount, freezing salaries and asking staff to work fewer hours. In times of crisis, there may be less loyalty to Singapore and Singaporeans.

An increased presence of international firms could also affect the ability of local firms to obtain high quality hires, as they cannot afford to compete with the starting salary often offered by these larger firms. This might appear like free-market economics at its best and it would be so if we were only talking about commercial areas, the mainstay of foreign firms. But this may mean fewer quality graduates entering into domestic disciplines, such as family law and criminal law. These areas tend to be dominated by smaller firms which are already struggling today to find lawyers to hire. There is a serious risk that these practice areas may be hollowed out.

Page: 1112

Could the Minister clarify the gaps in the current regime this move is intended to address? Does the Minister foresee our legal industry heading in the direction of Hong Kong where international law firms dominate nearly every area of the law, and local firms have all but disappeared? Is this a consequence the Government is prepared to accept? I also hope the Minister can clarify the nature of the conditions which will be imposed on the foreign firms to take up equity stakes, whether such conditions will be made public and how his Ministry intends to ensure that these conditions are obeyed. With that, Sir, I support the Bill.

Mr Pritam Singh : Thank you, Mr Speaker. Firstly, I would like to thank the Ministry for re-considering the original amendments in light of public feedback and the legal fraternity's reservations to some of the proposed changes to the Legal Profession (Amendment) Bill.

It is noteworthy that the Ministry has decided to delete the proposed amendment to section 35 after public feedback, in light of one of the central pillars of arbitration – party autonomy; in recognition of the fact that clients should be free to choose whoever they believe is best suited to represent them in arbitration proceedings. I understand many in the arbitral community welcome this view, and the Law Ministry should be commended for doing away with this proposed amendment.

Mr Speaker, it leaves me to pass some views on the ad hoc admission of Queen's Counsel. According to the MinLaw public consultation paper on the amendments, the original manifestation of this amendment called for a proposed licensing scheme that would give rights of audience in the local courts to a small number of "independent counsel". The purpose of this licensing scheme, according to the consultation paper, was to address the shortage of Senior Counsel in commercial and financial disputes. However, after feedback, MinLaw noted that preference was for Queen's Counsel to be admitted on an ad hoc basis, rather than through the Licensing Scheme.

Page: 1113

But while the current amendments ostensibly seek to make it easier to admit QCs for commercial disputes, it also statutorily raises the threshold for the admittance of Queen's Counsel from criminal cases to other areas of domestic law, such as family, constitutional and administrative law. What this suggests is that the freedom of Singaporeans to choose the appropriate counsel for legal advice is going to be statutorily curtailed as clause 4 amends section 15(2) to say "any area of law prescribed for the purposes of this section", rather than just criminal matters, as it currently stands. Effectively, the amendments set out two standards, both of which are clearly not spelt out in the Bill, but are understood to be those stated in the consultation papers.

There was some opposition to the amendment to section 15 from the public, I understand, and the Ministry replied noting that the Court still had the discretion to decide whether to admit Queen's Counsel on a case-by-case basis, effectively stating that such Counsel can still be admitted in cases involving domestic areas and that the factors taken into consideration in such an application would be a matter for the court to decide. This position from the Ministry then begs the question: why is there a need to amend section 15, especially since any application to admit a Queen's Counsel remains a matter for the court to decide?

Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps the desire of the Ministry to open the door to QCs in commercial matters is an opportune time to consider whether the courts should be left to decide whether the admittance of QCs would be necessary or not. It is noteworthy that public confidence in our judicial system is not low. Insofar as the proposed amendment to section 15 is concerned, the changes effectively operate to narrow the scope of the judiciary's flexibility to allow the admittance of QC and statutorily sets an even higher threshold for family, administrative and constitutional matters, amongst others. A more propitious course of action would be to allow the judiciary to assess each case, regardless of area of law – commercial or otherwise – on its own merits, and to assess whether the questions of law or fact necessitate the admittance of a QC.

Mr Speaker, Sir, over the years, albeit in a handful of significant cases, some local lawyers have found it difficult to engage senior local lawyers to act in cases where there were political overtones. Like the admission of Queen's Counsel for complex commercial and financial disputes – which is what this Bill ostensibly seeks to address – in the same vein, there is a concern that the door to entry for QCs should not be restricted for politically-charged cases either because senior local lawyers are reluctant to accept such briefs, or that only very few are willing to do so.

Sir, there are, of course, many pros and cons to keeping the door ajar for a Queen's Counsel. A natural response would be that opening the door to them could take away work for local lawyers. This concern should not be taken lightly. But to mitigate this, any individual or corporate who seeks redress in a local court should expect to make clear to the Bench why he or she needs a foreign lawyer, regardless if the case involves commercial law or local law – my view, Sir, is that it is simply a case of one standard for all, with the courts, not Parliament, determining that standard and applying it equally across all legal practice areas.

This would result in greater consistency insofar as the development of Singapore law as a whole is concerned, rather than the current proposed amendment which could portend a bifurcation in the development of Singapore law in the years to come – a highly up-to-date common law on commercial matters to the benefit of businesses, but a regime that could be behind the curve on local jurisprudential matters to the detriment of Singaporeans, as the brightest international legal brains have many more hoops to negotiate before being allowed to take on a domestic matter. To a lesser extent, the diminished prospects of local lawyers being invited to advise clients in foreign jurisdictions on non-commercial matters or penning cutting-edge academic commentary on local law could also be apparent over time when compared against their commercial colleagues.

Page: 1114

Mr Speaker, Sir, in light of the fundamental changes to the local legal landscape over the past few years, especially with the entry of foreign lawyers and law firms, some local lawyers fear that the Government has gone too far in its drive to liberalise the legal sector, and that the qualified entry of QCs for commercial matters is but evidence of this – an about-turn in view of the judicial impetus to develop Singapore law from the 1990s and the appointment of local Senior Counsels to practically remove the necessity of QCs.

To some Singaporeans, there is a concern that opening the door for QCs in commercial matters is myopically driven by economic interests alone as the international corporates may seek to extract quid pro quo from the Government, that is, if you want us to come and invest, we want to bring our own lawyers. Mr Speaker, this emotive can be quite strong in small and medium-sized firms. Opening the door to QCs, especially in areas of law that are financially lucrative, is perceived by some to further prejudice the prospects of small and medium-sized firms who cannot compete.

I am of the view that the judiciary and not Parliament is best placed to decide if any case heard locally warrants the admittance of a QC, regardless of the area of law. Parliament need not over legislate, but allow the judiciary space to shape the contours of Singapore's legal development in an independent way, keeping in mind the interests of local and foreign lawyers, and, of course, the local Bar. With that, Mr Speaker, thank you.

The question is whether these implications have been comprehensively thought through and systemically addressed by the Ministry. There must be sound policy reasons in support of them in order to justify these changes.

My understanding is that the main policy reason for giving QCs more scope to appear in Singapore courts is to address what is perceived to be a shortage of elite lawyers in Singapore who can represent opposing parties in high-end commercial and financial disputes before our courts.
