The fundamental question here is whether or not the policy reason behind the proposed changes is indeed a sound one.

Page: 1116

Let us examine the premise behind the policy rationale and the underlying assumptions. The main assumption is that there is a shortage of sufficiently qualified lawyers in Singapore who are capable of representing parties in certain specialised areas of law, in particular high-end commercial and financial disputes. Allow me to share with this House that this assumption has been met with much disquiet at the local Bar. A case may certainly be made for the appearance of independent counsels for cases involving areas of law that are unfamiliar to Singapore lawyers or where there are potential conflicts of interests should any arise. However, I do not agree with the view that there is an actual shortage of talent who are capable and qualified.

Let us pause and make a balanced and fair analysis that is accurately rooted in factual realities. First, I think the fiction that there is a dearth of experienced and competent lawyers within our local Bar is one that can easily be debunked on the facts. To date, we have a total of 68 appointed Senior Counsels, most of whom have many years of litigation experience. They occupy diverse positions within the legal fraternity and some have accepted judicial positions on the High Court Bench. Do we really lack the breadth and expertise in our Senior Counsels' ranks and other practising litigators to take on complex cases, even those that fall within specialised areas of law? I think not. On the contrary, our local Bar is extremely privileged in terms of its membership. It comprises exceptional luminaries who can clearly hold their ground and more than measure up to some of the best litigators in the Commonwealth.

Perhaps, then, the issue is one of conflict of interest. In essence, the issue here may be that there are insufficient qualified Counsels who will litigate against a big MNC or a bank but this concern is also questionable. The Bar includes stellar litigators who do not necessary hail from the big firms and who will be in a position to take on larger institutions. A few outstanding examples are Mr Kenneth Tan, Mr Michael Hwang and Mr Chelva Rajah. Two of these three litigators were appointed Judicial Commissioners before returning to private practice as leading litigators. So, is there really a need to have QCs to fill a gap that does not seem to exist?

Proponents of the proposed changes have raised attractive arguments for widening the scope of admission of QCs. Yet, these purported benefits should not be allowed to obscure the real question at hand. Is the existing arrangement, which already allows for the ad hoc appointment of QCs to argue cases locally, not an adequate framework within which these objectives can already be fulfilled? I repeat: is the existing arrangement, which already allows for the ad hoc appointment of QCs to argue cases locally, not an adequate framework within which these objectives can already be fulfilled?

It may be prudent, Sir, at this point in time to consider the rationale for the Senior Counsel scheme in Singapore and why it was even implemented in the first place, to take a leaf from the speech of the learned Member, Mr Hri Kumar. The appointment of Senior Counsel was a formal recognition of the emergence of highly specialised litigators in Singapore. The position of Senior Counsel was intended to be analogous to the rank of Queen's Counsel in England. The appointments were precisely intended to encourage home-grown advocates instead of reliance on the ad hoc admission of Queen's Counsels. The selection process is a highly rigorous one, carried out by a selection committee comprising the hon Chief Justice, hon Attorney General, and Judges of Appeal. In appointing a member of the Bar as Senior Counsel, the committee must be of the opinion that by virtue of the person's ability, his standing at the Bar, or special knowledge or experience in law, the person is deserving of such a distinction. Such stringent qualifying criteria, as well as the intention behind the scheme, which is the grooming and nurturing of a slate of Singapore advocates, are compelling counter-arguments to the need to allow more QCs to appear in local courts.

Page: 1117

As stated earlier, by virtue of the qualifying criteria, the quality and capabilities of our current Senior Counsels (SCs) are virtually guaranteed. Even if specialised knowledge is required from foreign sources who may be better versed in specific areas of law, are present demands not sufficiently met within the existing framework which already allows for the ad hoc admission of QCs and their equivalents on a case-by-case basis? It is evident that the courts have, thus far, taken a fair and reasonable approach which enables the special expertise of QCs to be tapped on when needed. Would widening the scope to allow more representation by foreign counsels better serve existing needs? Or are there potential adverse implications to such a move that would render it possibly unfeasible?

Mr Speaker, Sir, if the main rationale underlying the SC scheme is to nurture "home-grown advocates of the highest calibre", then is not the proposed liberalisation an effective reversal of that policy? How will allowing more QCs in to represent parties in local courts enhance the quality our local Bar? To be a high-quality litigator, one has to go to court regularly and fight cases of significance. One of the dangers of over liberalisation, from the perspective of developing a high-quality Bar at least, is the risk of alienating lawyers in the middle and junior ranks who are the very people who need the experience in order to build up their legal skills and expertise. The counter-argument that our younger lawyers would actually benefit from having the guidance and counsel of these elite lawyers is, in reality, a weak one. The truth is that these foreign counsels will likely look out for and work with their own juniors in London in strategising and preparing for their case. Where, then, is there space for a Singapore lawyer to learn in that environment?

Another issue that emerges from the proposed changes is that it could convey the message that the local Bar lacks expertise. The Law Society has rightly expressed concern in a submission that removing the criteria about complexity and circumstances of the case would send the signal that these issues were no longer relevant. Accordingly, QCs should only get admitted if, for some exceptional reason, the expertise they are offering is not available from local lawyers.

The proposed amendment should send a stronger signal in acknowledging the public interest in having a strong and independent local Bar. This leads us to consider our very own legal heritage. There is something unique about the Singapore Bar: its own unique and precious tradition, its own blend of jurisprudence, its own motion of court craft. What will happen to our traditions if we are overly open to foreign QCs arguing cases in our Singapore courts? I am not a protectionist, but we should not be so open as to rock the foundations.

This leads me to my next point. Another important reason why we cannot be overly reliant on foreign talent in the context of our legal profession is because our lawyers are the talent pool that feeds the High Court Bench. Currently, we have an excellent Bench. I am personally grateful to have been trained by many eminent judges when I was a junior judicial officer. Many of them were top litigators in their cohorts. They look at a case, dissect it, decide it through their wealth of knowledge in the law, but also, and importantly, by relying on the reservoir of experiences they accumulated as litigators in private practice. The local Bar is supposed to produce such men and women of top calibre to sit on the Bench. We should pause and recollect that the Bench is an integral institution in the separation of powers our Constitution envisions. It must be staffed with the best and most capable minds, as it is now, who have experienced the marinade of courtroom advocacy over many years. QCs cannot be appointed to our Bench. They are not Singaporeans. So, will an over-reliance on QCs rob Singapore of the talent she continues to require of those who sit on her Bench?

Page: 1118

This Bill is unlike the liberalisation of the accountancy sector, an imperfect analogy which some have attempted to draw, as accounting firms do not feed any institution of government. We must look far ahead and consider who will then sit on the Bench. Ultimately, this ties in with the broader issue, which is: what is the direction in which the Singapore litigation landscape will develop? To answer this question as I near the end of my speech, I quote a reassuring pronouncement of the hon Chief Justice Chan Sek Keong at the Opening of the Legal Year this year. The Chief Justice stated, "We can expect amending legislation to be enacted this year. The Bar can rest assured that this will not be a free for all. The Courts will admit ad hoc expert counsel on the basis of need and not simply because a litigant can afford to pay. We do not want to disadvantage litigants who cannot afford equivalent representation nor do we want to impede the nurturing of our own Senior Counsels, so ad hoc admission will be on a case-by-case basis with the Court doing a judicious balancing of competing interests in each case."

The Chief Justice's words artfully marry the need for liberalisation with the preservation of our legal traditions for the benefit of parties and the profession as a whole. Like I said before, I am not a protectionist and I can fully appreciate the difficult task the Minister for Law has before him: that of a clear realisation that Singapore must remain global and porous to attract the best and to provide the best service the world can offer while at the same time personally realising that fundamentals, which have served our unique legal tradition well, should not be discarded or usurped by untested foreign forces too quickly. It is a fine balance but one I am confident that the Minister will strike very well.

The jury is out whether this Bill will be the Bar's Valentine, but if the Minister gives his assurance that the possible negative effects will be kept in check, this liberalisation may pave a win-win for practitioners, and most importantly, Singapore's legal institutions an evolving heritage. It is with this optimism that I support the Bill.

Members will recall that the Chief Justice spoke about this in 2010 and 2011. This Bill is being moved in 2012 because my Ministry took a considerable time in getting feedback and having discussions on the issue. In that context, we wanted feedback from every segment of the legal profession – the Senior Counsel Forum which comprises all the SCs, the major law firms, as well as the medium and small law firms. The clear overwhelming preference among the small and medium law firms was that they wanted this. The Senior Counsel Forum was a little less clear.

What we had put forward originally was the idea that we will have three or four lawyers who would be given a licence to practise. Indeed, it is the reverse, because there are not too many Senior Counsels in small and medium-sized law firms, as I just gave Members the figures. Often, what happens in reality is that many of our banks or large corporations − which is the kind of case we are talking about – will go to a major law firm. They will get an SC and the other side may go, sometimes not infrequently, to a small or medium-sized law firm, something along the lines of Mr Lim Biow Chuan's law firm.

The first thing for the client to ask is – it is human psychology – the other side has an SC, am I going to get an SC? Even if Mr Lim or his peers are entirely competent to handle the case, the psychology is, can I have an SC? And then the problem starts because the firm will hunt around for an SC and, often, and I can only quote what the Chief Justice said, "they will find it difficult to get an SC". It has happened − I am not saying it is 100% − but it has happened frequently enough for the Chief Justice to have noted it and mentioned it twice, and put it in very concrete terms, that there needs to be an amendment.

So, it is in that context and which is why when we consulted the small, medium-sized law firms, they were overwhelmingly in support of this recommendation. It benefits the small man – small, as in the individual – but you do need to pay for a QC obviously; so I do not mean financial means. But for the individual or person who is prepared to fight, it benefits that person. At the same time, MAS and the banks also welcome this because it gives them greater flexibility. So, on different ends of the scale, people welcome this approach.

As for the Members' queries on the criteria for admission, the changes give the discretion to the Court to admit foreign counsel on a case-by-case basis. Mr Hri Kumar asked if I can set out the criteria. I think what is being done is not radical. If you look at clause 4, the original provision, section 15, reads: "Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Act, the court may, for the purpose of any one case where the court is satisfied that it is of sufficient difficulty and complexity and having regard to the circumstances of the case, admit to practise as an advocate and solicitor ...". We have proposed to remove the phrase, "where the court is satisfied that it is of sufficient difficulty and complexity and having regard to the circumstances of the case", basically, reverting to the 1991 position, which is the subject of a case law. There are criteria and guidance on what sort of factors the courts would have to take into account and, going further, bearing in mind the Chief Justice's remarks in the Opening of the Legal Year this year, that it is not to be a free-for-all. And the courts want to be very careful about admissions, precisely for the kind of reasons that Mr de Souza spoke about.

Page: 1121

We are amending the section to have an additional provision which gives the courts greater flexibility in identifying the factors and gazette it so that it is transparent. And the Chief Justice has made it clear that it would be a fairly strict approach and that is an indication that has been given. The Chief Justice has given guidance, in his speech, on the approach the courts will take.

For the balance between Parliament, the Legislature and the courts, Mr Singh feels that we should give more discretion to the courts; others here feel that we should set it out. I agree it is a question of getting the right balance. It is a question of judgement in these matters because each case can turn on its own facts. My own preference is to tilt more towards giving discretion to the courts with the general guidance of setting up the framework in the legislation, and that is what we seek to do, by removing the phrase "of sufficient difficulty and complexity".

Mr Singh also made a number of other points on this area. I think his first point was, why amend section 15 because it already gives the courts discretion? I went through clause 4 of the Bill – what it does is that it removes some phrases, and as a result of that, it gives the courts greater discretion. So I am not sure that we are on different wavelengths. I think the purpose of the amendments is actually to give the courts greater discretion in complex civil matters.

The second point that Mr Singh made was that there may be, as a result of these amendments, a bifurcation – I think this is what he said – where in commercial law cases, the quality of the lawyers would be much higher and would be international, whereas in criminal cases, the quality would be lower because it is more difficult to admit foreign lawyers in that area. Bearing in mind the courts continue to retain the discretion to admit QCs or foreign counsel even for those cases – I think we accept that the bar is different − would it result in this bifurcation? That argument proceeds from an assumption that I do not share, which is that local lawyers are simply not good enough. I do not agree because − of course, in any profession, there will be a gradation − if we can accept that the best of the local lawyers will be equal to the best anywhere in the world, then there should be no bifurcation.

The real rationale for the approach here is that in complex civil cases, for the reasons that I have given, we frequently find that the litigants are unable to engage the best of the SCs that they do want to engage. That is the problem. If we accept that to be a problem -- and I have quoted the Chief Justice a number of times and I accept what he says -- then we will see immediately why a distinction can be drawn between criminal cases and civil cases, because in criminal cases, we do not have that problem. There is no difficulty for any top SC accepting a brief in a criminal, constitutional, or public case because there is no real issue of conflict. Or even if there is no direct conflict, it is not as if the law firm is on a retainer which prevents any particular SC from taking up a case on a public or constitutional criminal matter.

Page: 1122

Underlying Mr Singh's questions was another thread, which is probably his real question: would local lawyers be afraid or unwilling to act in, say – I cannot remember whether it was he or Mrs Chiam who used the words – "political-type cases" or libel cases. I think that suggestion would do local lawyers some injustice because I do believe, at the end of the day, local lawyers will step up to handle any case where they feel that representation is necessary. I am not one to cite my personal experiences frequently, but the fact that I was in a large firm that dealt with many matters for Government-linked corporations did not preclude me from acting in a libel case for The International Herald Tribune (IHT) against the then-Prime Minister, Senior Minister and Deputy Prime Minister. It is really the timbre of the man and not this supposed fear, that matters. Mr Singh made a further point that international corporations – I think he did not use the word "blackmail" – may say they would not come into Singapore unless they bring their own QCs. I am not sure international corporations will say it in those terms, but the sense of MAS and the banks is that greater flexibility obviously helps us in becoming a more attractive centre for business. Here, again, we have to carefully weigh the advantages. My reasons given earlier on as to why we need to make this move in the context of the learned Chief Justice's remarks are good and independent, and stand by themselves about the representation against large corporates and banks. But independent of that, if the financial services sector would benefit from a slightly more liberal approach to the admission of QCs, then that is in the interests of Singaporeans as a whole, even if it results in a few cases where local lawyers may be employed as the second Counsel. Here, it is a weighing of the interests, and I think we have to go by the judgement of the professionals, that is, the financial services industry and what MAS thinks about the matter.

Mrs Chiam, and Mr Singh as well, suggested, does this represent a U-turn? It does represent going back to the position in 1991. We had the position from 1991 to now. We have built up a corps of SCs. But we cannot stand still even if the situation calls for a review. The situation calls for a review because of the factors that I have highlighted. The changes were asked for by the courts, and we believe those changes are necessary and the point is a legitimate one.

I now turn to Mr Kumar's and Mr de Souza's comments about foreign law practices with share ownership in Singapore law practices. The first point to make in this is that this is not really a fundamental change because section 130(l) of the Act already allows that. It allows foreign lawyers in their personal capacities to hold shares in Singapore law practices. All that this amendment does is, not just foreign lawyers, but also allows law practices to have that sort of ownership. And it gives the Singapore law firms – and that is important to emphasise – the flexibility. Firms may now allow foreign share ownership through allowing lawyers or a structure for firm-to-firm tie-ups.

Another point which I think needs to be emphasised is that these changes do not mandate or direct the Singapore law firm to do anything. What these changes do is to give greater flexibility to the Singapore law firms. The underlying fear in some of the speeches is that once we give that flexibility, Singapore law firms will do these things and, lo and behold, what will happen?

Page: 1123

What is the duty of the Government in this context? Do we try and hold the line when the local law firms come to us and ask for this flexibility because they see the international scene changing and they need to change with that? Or to believe that we know better than them on how they should structure their business relationships? Law firms which believe that this is not the way to go do not need to do these things. This is only a provision that allows such measures to allow law firms to decide what is in their own best interest, rather than we doing it by dicta.

A consistent feedback that we have received from law firms is that the current regime is too constraining. It does not allow them to structure business models and strategies that would allow them to compete effectively with international firms which are increasingly dominating the high-value cross-border transactions. Even our larger and stronger law firms have told my Ministry that they do not have the international presence and network to compete and that they can only acquire such competencies and capabilities through closer partnerships with foreign firms. Mr Kumar asked if we will become like Hong Kong, where international firms dominate several areas of the law. I had earlier said that the international legal services market is an intensely competitive one. In 2007, the Committee to Develop the Singapore Legal Sector issued its report. That report highlighted the importance of helping our Singapore law practices to capture a greater share of the regional market even as we attract more foreign law practices to Singapore as a base for regional work. Among other measures, we amended the Legal Profession Act in 2008 and issued six Qualifying Foreign Law Practice Licences which allowed foreign law firms to practise in the permitted areas of Singapore law, notably commercial, corporate and financial law. That scheme has achieved its objective of bringing in more international legal work to Singapore. About 80% of the revenue of the QFLPs amounting to about $170 million was derived from offshore work in the second year of their licences. At the same time, the QFLPs have provided substantial opportunities for our young Singaporean lawyers. The QFLP scheme was not the first step in the liberalisation of the sector. As the House will note, we have incrementally allowed foreign law firms to enter our industry through various frameworks, beginning with the former Law Alliance in 2000.

The hard reality is that when it comes to liberalising the legal services sector, there are really only two feasible options: one, we could have decided in 2000 to keep the industry closed, and some other jurisdictions have done that. But in the end, we will find that that will only hurt the profession and deprive young Singapore lawyers of opportunities to hone their skills working on complex international deals. Our financial and economic sectors, which are highly international and open, would be limited by the lack of sophisticated legal services support that global financial institutions are familiar with in other financial centres in the world. I do not for a moment suggest that the lawyers here who spoke up do so out of self-interest. That is obviously not so. But there will be a legitimate question that the Government would have to answer as to why do we have opening up in the banking sector, in the accounting sector, in so many sectors, and as a result we get all of them coming into Singapore and employing Singaporeans, providing job opportunities, and why is the legal sector so special that it needs to be protected completely? That is a question that will be asked. Unless Members can offer a compelling answer to that question, I think the answer must be that we have no choice but to open up.

Page: 1124

Second, the only other realistic choice, instead of keeping it completely closed, is to continue to liberalise the practice of law in Singapore, and there are many different approaches. We could have gone for a Big Bang approach and liberalised completely. But we started in 2000; this is 2012. And in a large measure, the profession continues to be protected. We have taken very, very incremental steps. And other Members in this House have spoken up about why we are not liberalising even faster. The reason why we took this incremental step-by-step approach is to give our law firms the opportunity to level up, tie up, bulk up, consolidate, increase their revenues and size so that they can compete, or create a framework which makes it easier for them to tie up with foreign firms on a reasonable basis. That has been our approach.

At each juncture, when we change the law in this area, we have looked at our national imperatives and market needs while keeping as a key prerogative also the interest of the legal profession in Singapore. Can Singapore firms compete? It is a question, Sir, I have dealt with a number of times since I took office as Minister for Law. Looking at the international trends: a jurisdiction like Germany – one of the largest countries in the world and the second top exporting economy in the world – finds it difficult to sustain local home-grown law firms in the context of the internationalised environment. If we look at German industry and German strengths in local business and we compare it with Singapore and our open nature and relatively service-oriented economy, there is simply no comparison. The way the international legal scene is moving is fairly clear. We have to deal with that. In the interest of Singaporeans as a whole, my statements since 2008 have been consistent on the need for firms to collaborate, consolidate because size will allow them the advantage of accessing technology to enhance their ability to compete in the developing international legal market. Survival in this environment depends on ourselves, on our law firms and how flexible and nimble they are. And I speak from experience because from 2000 to 2008, I was in the law firm which had to deal with all these issues and which was in a major tie-up. I know the importance of access to technology, access to the latest legal know-how and the need to bulk up.

Firms which wish to embrace this new environment ought to be allowed to do so, and that is what these provisions provide. The central changes allow our local law firms to enter into closer partnership with foreign firms. The decision about whether to do so lies entirely with our local law firms. If they believe that they do not need to do any of these things and they can survive and can compete, then they may do so. But that is no reason for preventing others from wanting to tie up.

Let me address at this point Mr de Souza's concern that foreign firms are often driven by the balance sheet of their headquarters. He made the point that foreign firms that may lay off people, do so. Every law firm, while it is a professional entity, is also a business operation. That is a reality today. If we do not accept that, I think we are probably not in keeping with modern reality. So whether it is a local or foreign law firm, they would look at business conditions to determine how many lawyers they need. And the practices of foreign law firms on hiring and firing may well be more economically driven, perhaps, than local law firms, I do not want to make a specific comment on that. I note what Mr de Souza says. Surely, that is a matter for local lawyers to decide before they join such law firms. But on the other hand, I get x percentage more per month, right upfront, and the prospect of working in London, New York, Hong Kong and many Singaporeans have become partners in foreign law firms. 5.03 pm

Mr K Shanmugam : Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time." Today's amendments will enhance the court's discretion to consider relevant evidence by widening the admissibility of: (i) computer output evidence; (ii) hearsay evidence; and (iii) opinion evidence.

At the same time, other amendments deal with procedural justice including: (i) the confidentiality of legal advice to be enhanced by widening legal professional privilege; and (ii) a rule on the evidence of character in rape cases will be repealed.

The Bill has benefited from: (i) the views of professors at the Law Faculty of NUS; (ii) the 2003 consultation paper and the 2004 report on computer output as evidence by the Technology Law Development Group of the Singapore Academy of Law; (iii) the 2011 report on opinion evidence by the Law Reform Committee of the Singapore Academy of Law; and (iv) other legal stakeholders. We thank all who have contributed.

Let me now explain the key amendments. On computer output evidence, clauses 3, 7, 9, 10, 12 and 13 reform the law on computer output evidence. The current framework for the admission of computer output evidence is found in sections 35 and 36. They were introduced in 1996. Computer technology was then in its infancy. A cautious approach was therefore taken. Currently, short of agreement between parties, computer output can be admitted only if: (i) it is produced in an approved process; or (ii) it is shown to be produced by a properly operating computer which was properly used.

This is a somewhat cumbersome process not consonant with modern realities. With the benefit of experience, we can say now that computer output evidence should not be treated differently from other evidence. Sections 35 and 36 are therefore repealed. In addition, there will be presumptions facilitating the admission of electronic records. For example, where a device is one that, if properly used, accurately communicates an electronic record, it will be presumed that an electronic record communicated by that device was accurately communicated. Sounds a little circular, but it does make sense. Further, documents in the form of electronic records will be treated as primary evidence.

Page: 1128

Let me now move to hearsay. Clauses 5, 6, 11 and 19 deal with the admissibility of hearsay evidence. The hearsay rule provides that an out-of-court statement shall not be admitted as proof of its contents, unless the maker of the statement is produced in court. The rule has been much criticised and exceptions have been carved out. Strong views have been expressed to us that the hearsay rule should be abolished. The present amendments, however, do not go that far. There is still a core of sense – commonsense − in the hearsay rule that, prima facie, a statement should not be admitted to prove the truth of its contents if its maker cannot be cross-examined as to its veracity. What we have done is to introduce more flexible exceptions to the hearsay rule.

Section 32 is amended, so that the exceptions in that section will no longer be predicated on the unavailability of the maker. The business records exception in section 32(b) is extended. Existing exceptions under the Criminal Procedure Code 2010 will now be moved to the Evidence Act; they will now apply to both civil and criminal proceedings. The court is given a residual discretion to exclude hearsay evidence in the interests of justice. This ensures that the expanded exceptions are not abused. This is in addition to the court's inherent jurisdiction to exclude prejudicial evidence. A party who intends to rely on hearsay evidence would also have to give advance notice of his intent, in accordance with the relevant rules of procedure.

Clause 8 deals with expert opinion. Currently, expert opinion is only admissible in respect of points: (i) of foreign law; (ii) of science or art; (iii) or as to the identity and genuineness of handwriting or finger impressions. This description does not exhaust the range of expert opinion which may be helpful to the court. All points of scientific, technical or other specialised knowledge will now be made admissible. It is also provided that expert opinion is not inadmissible merely because it relates to a matter of common knowledge. This widens the cases where the court can have the benefit of an expert's views, if it so desires. As in the case of hearsay, the court will have the discretion to exclude expert opinion in the interests of justice. This is in addition to the court's inherent jurisdiction to exclude prejudicial evidence.

Next, I turn to legal professional privilege. Clauses 4, 14, 15, 16 and 17 deal with legal professional privilege. The privilege will be extended to communications with in-house legal counsel which is made for the purpose of seeking legal advice. This includes legal counsel employed by public agencies, including the Government, the Attorney-General's Chambers and statutory boards. The privilege will apply to interpreters and other persons, who work under the supervision of in-house legal counsel. These changes allow advice to be sought from in-house legal counsel in full confidence. The privilege will not protect communications made in furtherance of any illegal purpose, or prevent from disclosure any fact observed by legal counsel which shows that a crime or fraud has been committed.

Next, clause 18, on the character of sexual assault victims. Clause 18 repeals section 157(d). The sub-section provides that the credit of the victim in a rape or attempted rape case may be impeached by showing that she is of generally immoral character. This provision has existed since 1872. It is premised on antediluvian assumptions that a sexually active woman is less worthy of credit. It gives an opening for sexual assault victims to be subjected to gratuitous, traumatising and insulting cross-examination. The Office for Women's Development under the Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports had given us feedback that this amendment ought to be made. Likewise, AWARE also gave us feedback that this provision ought to be deleted, by making this amendment. When the amendment is made, any cross-examination of a sexual assault victim must proceed on the basis of relevance. I thank both MCYS and AWARE for raising this issue with us and helping us on this particular issue.

Page: 1129

In conclusion, the remaining clauses relate to definitional, consequential and other minor amendments.

These are part of the Ministry of Law's continuing law reform efforts in what is primarily a procedural Act. Sir, I beg to move.

Similar language is employed for in-house legal counsel but the distinction is not so clear. We can have a situation where an in-house legal counsel is employed by a company. A fraud then occurs within that company and management wants to go to the in-house counsel and seek advice on that fraud. Surely, privilege should attach to that situation but under the wording of the Act, privilege will not cover any fraud or crime which occurs after that in-house counsel has been employed.

But because the same language is used for both section 128 and proposed section 128A, I think some uncertainties will arise. I will be grateful for the Minister's clarification on that.

Page: 1131

Next, it is on the issue of hearsay. Many of our laws and rules on hearsay are based on out-dated concerns or irrelevant principles. In the foreword to Prof Jeffrey Pinsler's book, Evidence and the Litigation Process, the Honourable the Chief Justice Chan Sek Keong recognised that many of the rules of evidence, including those related to expert opinion evidence and hearsay, are based on jury trials where evidence may have a tendency to prejudice the minds of jurors is excluded from their consideration. Different considerations should apply in Singapore where all trials are Bench trials and the finder of fact is the judge.

In proposing amendments to the law on opinion evidence and hearsay, the Ministry of Law in its press release noted that these amendments would save significant legal time and costs for litigants by preventing unnecessary technical challenges on the admissibility of certain kinds of evidence. It would also help ensure that all the relevant evidence is before the court hearing the matter, whether criminal or civil, thus enhancing access to justice. With regard to expert opinion evidence, the Ministry expressed that the current limited approach was unnecessary because our judges are capable of appreciating the subtleties of expert opinion evidence and according the appropriate weight to it. And I agree with this approach. The considerations that were applied to lay people in the 19th century who sat in the jury box were completely out of place in our legal system.

It is for this reason that I think there is some merit to re-examine whether the hearsay rule should be abolished completely. What we have introduced by these amendments are rules that allow for broader admission of hearsay evidence but keep in place some of the technical rules which may keep out some evidence. Instead of making incremental changes that leave these technical rules and then add layers of discretion, we should just do away with the rules regarding hearsay evidence altogether, as we have effectively done for the rules regarding opinion of experts. Any evidence should be made admissible as long as it is relevant. It is for the judges to decide what weight to allocate to that piece of evidence, and they are equipped to make that assessment and, in fact, do this all the time.

As noted by Prof Chin Tet Yung in an article written over 20 years ago in the Malayan Law Review, confidence is already placed in judges on a matter of admissibility, and to trust judges on admissibility and not on weight is spurious. A judge has undergone years of legal training and is entirely capable of exercising his discretion and according weight to each piece of evidence based on the circumstances of the case, factoring in considerations such as reliability, the reasons for the absence of the maker of the statement and the inability to cross-examine the maker. If the judge gets it wrong, the appellate court is there to put it right.

Prof Chin in the same article also noted that it has been argued that a relaxation of the hearsay rule will lead to a flood of unreliable evidence. He countered that this objection does not take into account the fact that at the end of the day, the judge will be looking for credible evidence and it is not in the interests of the litigant to put forward a mass of multiple hearsay statements. Lawyers are likely to rely on the best evidence possible and that may mean that hearsay evidence will usually play a secondary role. Based on my years of practice, I would agree with this.

From a broader point of view, removing technical rules should be seen as a positive development. It is often being said that not only must justice be done, justice must be seen to be done. Laws, to be effective and accepted, should be understood by the people whose lives they affect. Technical, archaic rules do not help that understanding. We should make our laws simpler. There are fewer legal minefields to navigate. Access to justice, and confidence in the legal system, will be improved.

Page: 1132

This proposed approach would also yield tangible benefits. For example, the rules on admissibility of hearsay evidence perpetuate the legal fiction that we find in our courts today. In a jury system, the judge decides on admissibility of evidence and if the evidence is ruled inadmissible, the jury never sees it and, therefore, it does not affect their decision or their reasoning. However, in our system, the judge who decides a case also views the evidence to decide if it is admissible. If he rules it inadmissible, he has to put it out of his mind when coming to his decision. But judges are human and this is an artificial exercise. They will remember what they saw, and it may affect their perception of the evidence. It would be better that they deal with such matters upfront and openly.

Doing away with the hearsay rule could reduce the number of appeals based on whether some evidence was improperly admitted or not admitted. It also addresses the problem that arises when an appellate court rules that a judge wrongly admitted or declined to admit evidence. The error made by the trial judge could impact how the judge considered other pieces of evidence. The appellate court then has the difficult task of deciding whether the trial judge would have ruled or applied his discretion differently if he had not made the error on admission.

So, I would propose that we simplify our laws, get rid of technical rules and make access to justice easier. With that, Sir, I support the Bill.

I am concerned that the harmonisation between civil and criminal cases should not be taken too far. I agree that the hearsay rules in civil cases can be relaxed, as they are unnecessary restrictive. The law thus has a default position of requiring the best and most reliable evidence. Witnesses should attend court to give oral evidence and be tested under cross-examination. What was said outside of court should only be considered under circumstances where there is no choice, such as when the witness is no longer available or when there is an assurance that the statement made outside of court is reliable and accurate.

Clause 5 of the Bill seeks to have a common regime for admitting hearsay evidence for both civil and criminal cases. The effect of clause 5 will be to enable out of court statements to be tended in court simply if the witness is unavailable, unable or refuses to testify in court. This concept is borrowed from section 270(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code (CPC). This Bill re-enacts part of the CPC provisions pertaining to hearsay evidence, to make them applicable to both civil and criminal cases under the Evidence Act.

Page: 1133

Because the Evidence Act now embodies combined hearsay provisions, the Ministry is proposing under clause 21 to delete the hearsay provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code (CPC), namely, sections 269 to 277. This massive deletion is, I believe, consequential. It appears to dilute the strictness of rules against hearsay evidence in criminal cases. For instance, under the current section 270(1) of the CPC which is to be deleted, it is provided that the court can admit hearsay evidence if the witness is no longer available, "subject €¦ to the rules of law governing the admissibility of accused's statements". The significance of this qualifying phrase was an important issue in the Court of Appeal case of Lee Chez Kee and Public Prosecutor [2008] 3 SLR (R) 447. In Lee's case, the accused was charged with committing a murder with two other persons. His two co-participants had been sentenced earlier. By the time of the accused's trial, one of them had already been executed, while the other had been deported to Malaysia and was untraceable. One of them had made statements to the police incriminating the accused. The issue arose at Lee's trial as to whether the unavailability of the co-participant made his earlier statements to police admissible against Lee.

The Court of Appeal considered this point extensively. One long-standing concern was that, in general, accomplice evidence is to be treated with suspicion. After all, it is human tendency to drag others down with you or to push blame to others to exonerate yourself. Thus, our laws provide that confessions by accomplices can only be considered if there is a joint trial of all accused; if there is no joint trial, the confessions should not be considered at all. This is found in section 258(5) of the CPC, which was formerly section 30 of the Evidence Act.

The Court of Appeal needed to consider whether the hearsay provisions in the CPC allowed hearsay evidence from accomplices who were unavailable. The court noted that the equivalent of section 270(1) clearly stated that hearsay could be admitted "subject to the rules of law governing the admissibility of accused's statements". Two out of the three Court of Appeal judges found that this qualification meant that accomplice statements should not be admitted under the hearsay exceptions, even if the accomplices were not available.

Sir, section 270 is now being deleted and the words "subject to the rules of law governing the admissibility of accused's statements" are not being ported over to the Evidence Act. The net result is that there is no longer any express mention that the rules against accomplice evidence will apply when admitting hearsay statements. Is this omission intentional? Is it the Government's intention to allow hearsay evidence from dead or unavailable accomplices in a criminal trial? This is clearly a very dangerous path to go down on.

Another result of the massive deletion of sections 269 to 277 of the CPC is that section 271(1) is also deleted. This section excluded statements made in the course of police investigations from being admitted in evidence even if the witness is unavailable or refuses to testify. This section was aimed at ensuring the witnesses attend court personally, and preserved the right of the accused to confront his accusers. Is this omission also intentional? Will the amendments undermine the protection against unreliable hearsay evidence in criminal trials?

In court, what this means is to know how to make good use of your expert witness against the other side.

This makes the area of law complex and the Law Reform Committee has fittingly recommended that both components be neatly codified in the Act, which will then allow the courts to develop the privilege within the parameters of statute. As it stands, the courts have to test the case law on litigation privilege for consistency with the codified provisions before they can apply them.

I move now to the hearsay amendments, and I have four brief technical points. First, clause 5(d), which introduces new subsection 32(1)(j)(i). This introduces the CPC hearsay exception where a statement is made out of court by a person who is now dead. This limb effectively subsumes existing section 32(1)(a), which is a narrow exception for statements made by a person when it relates to the cause of his death. Would there still therefore be a need for subsection (1)(a)?

Second, existing subsection (1)(c) may be too narrow an exception to the Hearsay Rule. Why should it relate only to the statements made against the maker's pecuniary or proprietary interest or when it exposes him to potential criminal prosecution or a suit for damages? How about reputational risks, or exposure to the risk of administrative or disciplinary action, for example? The principle underlying this exception to the hearsay rule is that when an out of court statement is made by a person against his own interests, then the reliability quotient of that statement rises, hence its admissibility. My recommendation is to amend this limb so that it refers principally to statements made against the interests of the maker generally and leave the rest as illustration or examples to demonstrate what it means.

For example, section 3(1)(c) of the South African Law of Evidence Amendment Act 1988 allows the court to admit hearsay evidence in the interest of justice, after considering various relevant factors.

Mr Vikram Nair (Sembawang) : Good evening, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir. Thank you for allowing me to speak on this. The Evidence Act, I think, as acknowledged by all speakers before me is an ancient Act. I think it started with the Evidence Ordinance of 1893 and was, I think, updated largely based on the Evidence Act of 1872. Now, many of the rules here were naturally developed in the era jury trials. I think the main purpose of an Evidence Act is two-fold. On the one hand, you want to get all the relevant evidence before a judge so that the judge can make the best possible decision. And that argument will allow a permissive view of evidence, meaning you should allow as much evidence in as possible. The countervailing interest it has to strike is to protect the interest of parties involved to make sure that it is only relevant evidence that is permitted against them. In an era of jury trials, that is especially important because prejudicial information may be based on hearsay, and that can still be very damaging.

It is in this respect that I have three comments to make. The first is on the liberalisation of many aspects of the rules for evidence. I think there are at least three examples of this. One is narrowing the scope of the Hearsay Rule; second is permitting computer output more generally; and third is allowing a broader range of expert evidence to be admitted.

Broadly speaking, what this means is that there will be more information before the judge which the judge would have to consider in making a decision. I also hear Ms Sylvia Lim's concern earlier on that in relation to criminal law, for example, maybe we should keep stronger admissibility rules in order to protect the accused. This is the tension I struggled with for a while. But the reason that I came down in favour of a more discretionary approach in the end was because, ultimately, if we trust the judge to make a decision on the admissibility, then that same judge can decide, "Look, I have admitted hearsay evidence but, at the same time, I would give it less weight." In a criminal case, in particular, the standard of proof is beyond reasonable doubt. So if a judge has to go on the basis of hearsay evidence alone, then the judge would be very slow to find beyond the reasonable doubt that the crime was committed.

Page: 1138

I would also say that, having practised in arbitration for the last couple of years, the rules of evidence, and certainly as it is stated in the Evidence Act, are not that strictly enforced by most arbitration tribunals. And quite often, hearsay evidence is admitted. But the reason it does not result in very great injustice is because the arbitrators are able to give the appropriate weight to evidence. And when they make findings of fact, they would obviously give more weight to direct evidence. Lawyers, likewise, know that direct evidence is more persuasive. So, on balance, I am in favour of taking a more liberal approach to allowing evidence, provided, of course, we trust the judge to either exclude evidence that they may find prejudicial which they have the power to do, or, alternatively, just give it less weight and not make a conviction on that ground.

The second point I would like to address is the abolition of section 157(d) of the Evidence Act. The reason why I think it is all right to allow less evidence in this particular section is because it protects the victim. More often than not, victims of rape would be reluctant to come forward anyway and having their entire previous sexual history brought up in court would definitely be an even greater deterrent. Let me now make a third point since everyone here is unanimous that rape victims should be protected. I think the main reason for abolishing this rule is that violence against women, non-consensual sex, is really the same, whether or not that happens in marriage or outside marriage. Mr K Shanmugam : Sir, I thank all the Members who have spoken. Mr Kumar spoke on the admissibility of hearsay evidence. He agrees that the hearsay rules should be reformed. But his suggestion of reform is, in fact, complete abolition, instead of piecemeal reform. His view is that the use of hearsay evidence should be left entirely to the discretion of the courts. The amendments proposed by my Ministry give the courts more discretion. Should we go further and completely abolish the rule? It is actually a fair point. Across the world, there is intense debate in many common law jurisdictions. South Africa, for instance, has abolished the hearsay rule altogether, giving the courts full discretion to admit or exclude hearsay in both civil and criminal proceedings. That approach has, however, not been without difficulties in practice. Some jurisdictions, after having considered the rule very carefully and whether it should be abolished, have decided to retain the rule.

What we seek to achieve is to try and rationalise the rule in the context of the developments, but fully accepting – and I say this to Mr Kumar and Members of the House – that this is not the end point. These amendments are not cast in stone. Mr Kumar has been in practice, others have been in practice and I have been in practice. I hear what Ms Sylvia Lim has said. And we will have to take seriously the suggestions and consider our experience as we go along. This set of amendments represents today what we believe to be the best balance that we can strike between the use of helpful hearsay evidence and the risk of presenting unreliable evidence before the courts. The net result of these amendments will be that the courts will have a broader but still structured discretion to deal with hearsay evidence.

Mr Desmond Lee agrees with our approach but raised a number of suggestions and refinements to the hearsay provisions. He first queried on section 32(1)(a) which provides the well-known dying declaration exception for hearsay evidence should be deleted in light of the new section 32(1)(j) which provides the general hearsay exception when a witness is dead or unavailable. There is an overlap between the two exceptions, a substantial overlap, I accept. If we started de novo today, I think there is a very strong case for saying we ought to have only one of the two provisions. But the reason why we decided to leave these two provisions alone is that there is really a very substantial body of case law not only from Singapore but around the world which has guided our courts. We would lose something by deleting when the courts have been able to get guidance on both provisions. As for Mr Lee's suggestion that the scope of section 32(1)(c) which provides the existing hearsay exception for statements made against the interests of the maker should perhaps be broadened, we will consider that suggestion. As I said, the current amendments are not cast in stone and we will consider whether there should be further amendments to broaden the definition of what amounts to against the interests of the maker of the statement.

Page: 1140

Mr Lee also suggested giving the courts a residual power to recognise new categories of hearsay evidence. He says this will ensure that the categories of admissible hearsay evidence under the exceptions are not closed and can grow over time as the justice of the case requires, and he referred to the South African legislation. But that really would be as good as abolishing the hearsay rule, which is what South Africa has done. I have indicated why we do not want to take that approach.

Mr Lee's fourth point was on the courts' general power to exclude prejudicial evidence, and queried if such a power should be made a statutory power in that it applies across all admissibility provisions. The courts' discretion to exclude hearsay or expert opinion evidence in the interest of justice, as set out in the Bill, is – and I emphasise this – in addition to its general power to exclude prejudicial evidence at common law. Such a general power stems from the courts' inherent jurisdiction, and our preference is to leave that unlegislated. Let us see how the courts exercise this power, whether it creates problems or whether it works well, and we will keep this under review.

Ms Sylvia Lim raised her fundamental point, even though she made it as a number of different points, is her concern that by harmonising civil and criminal cases for the hearsay exception rules to both civil and criminal cases, are we taking it too far, would evidence which is prejudicial to the accused now be admissible, and would that weaken supposedly the administration of justice and lead to – I suppose the point is only valid if, ultimately, it leads to – convictions which should not have been made in the interests of justice.

The short answer – I will give a general answer and then deal with the specific points that Ms Lim made – is I have made the point that there are contrasting arguments around the world as to whether we should have the hearsay rules or, in fact, abolish them altogether. Mr Hri Kumar argued strongly for the rules to be completely abolished. I do not think Mr Hri Kumar thinks that that would affect the administration of justice. The reason is simple. There is a strong argument to say that all relevant evidence should be presented to a court. Bear in mind the hearsay rules and other such exclusionary rules really developed in the context of jury trials and that juries will not be able to look at such evidence and weigh carefully the difference between direct evidence and hearsay evidence and give weight to one and give less weight to another, and it is really an assessment of the probative value of the evidence versus the prejudicial value of the evidence. The feeling was, in the context of hearsay in the context of criminal cases, the prejudicial impact on juries would outweigh the probative value. So, one should not take a sort of black-and-white approach to it. The black-and-white approach that should be taken is to the fundamental principle that the judge must at the end of the day be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt on the guilt of the accused, and we should set out clearly what the law disapproves of, which is evidence obtained by coercion and various categories which the law has set out. But when it comes to issues like hearsay, then there is the question of a judgement call. The structure we have put up is that we have set up some safeguards. We also give the overriding jurisdiction to the courts to exclude evidence, both in civil and criminal cases. So the courts continue to have that discretion. In fact, they are expressly given that discretion through these amendments. And do not forget that, even if the evidence is allowed in, there is the question of weight. The court could say: "This is relevant. I allow it in, but I give it very little weight."

Page: 1141

Let me refer to a specific example to illustrate what I mean. There is a famous Australian case in 1989 called Walton v The Queen. There was a statement by a three-year-old child. It is a famous and controversial case. The child's father was accused of murdering the child's mother. What happened is that the deceased handed over the telephone to the child and the child said "Hello, Daddy", which the witness heard. The witness gave that evidence in court. The child was considered to be too young to give evidence.

Now, look at the balance of interest. There is evidence that the child said on the phone, "Hello, Daddy", which I supposed would potentially allow someone to infer that the person on the other side of the line was his father. You have the woman who had been murdered. You have the interest of society in making sure that the person who committed the crime is found guilty. You have the interest and the rights of the accused that he not be found guilty except and unless the evidence is proven beyond reasonable doubt. In those circumstances, should such evidence be admissible? The court in the Australian case held the evidence to be inadmissible. It has been highly controversial. Could there be an argument that in the context where you have a hard-bitten, experienced judge hearing the case, you should allow that evidence but leave it to the judge to decide what weight is to be ascribed? Perhaps, very little. And perhaps in appropriate cases, as our amendments made clear, the evidence should be excluded altogether.

What we are doing now is not therefore to allow in what was previously not allowed but to give the courts the discretion to sieve through the evidence to see which part should be allowed if the judge believes that to be in the interests of justice in the particular case. We should not approach the cases and the evidence as a series of technical hurdles for the prosecution to jump. We must also remember that there is an interest of society in allowing relevant evidence, and that the judge is best placed to decide on what is relevant. We, in Parliament, should of course set out the framework. I accept that. The fundamental purpose behind this is not to change the ultimate golden thread which is that, in every case, the judge has to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt. It is to give him greater access to evidence when he or she believes that is going to be useful, and he still has the position on weight.

Specific points that Ms Lim made can be referenced by me going through specific clauses. The amendments do not simply expand the scope of admission of evidence, as Ms Lim notes. In some cases, they reduce the scope as well. Let me illustrate.

There are at present some categories of evidence which are admissible in criminal cases but not in civil cases. For example, written records are presently more readily admissible under the Criminal Procedure Code (CPC) which applies to criminal proceedings only, rather than the Evidence Act which applies to both criminal and civil proceedings. This is largely an anomaly; a matter of legislative history because the hearsay provisions of the Evidence Act are much dated and go way back while the hearsay provisions in the CPC were enacted in more modern times. And so the amendments seek to align the hearsay provisions. We have taken care to port over the hearsay provisions including the safeguards which are set out in the CPC. For example, how or in what context the hearsay evidence is referred to. If we look at the amendments to section 32, we now have a provision which ports over the reference to a person who is compellable but refuses to give evidence, or a person who is dead or cannot be found. There is also bringing over of paragraphs (a) to (j) of subsection (1), where a person makes an oral statement at the hearing of another person who at the request of the maker of the statement, puts it into writing. This is ported over from a contemporaneous records exception in section 270(2) of the CPC. And subsection (3) gives over-riding jurisdiction to the court to exclude evidence even if it falls within the exceptions. That is an important safeguard that we have introduced. Subsection (5) gives the court the discretion to assign the appropriate weight to hearsay evidence. Section 274(2) of the CPC, 274(3) of the CPC − all these now have been transported over.

Page: 1142

There is one other point I would like to make: Ms Lim's reference to the Court of Appeal's decision in the Lee Chez Kee v PP [2008] 3 SLR (R) 447 case on accomplice evidence; and on statements made to police, whether they would be admissible. Again, I come back to my central point. It does not mean that they are automatically admissible. They are only admissible if the court is satisfied as to why the maker cannot be produced and is also satisfied that there is some probative value and is also satisfied that the interests of justice require the statement to be admitted, and then the court decides on the weight to be accorded to such evidence.

Let me now turn to legal professional privilege. Mr Kumar touched on three issues. First, the application of the privilege in the context of search and seizure by the police. In particular, he queried about the situation whether privilege can be claimed or disputed during a police raid. Second, the possible abuse of the privilege provisions; and, third, the scope of section 128A(4).

On the first issue, I should first clarify that the Evidence Act relates largely to the admissibility of evidence for court proceedings. The amendments do not seek to deal directly with the privilege against search and seizure. That has to be dealt with under common law, the CPC and the other relevant statutes. I would say this though. The privilege is generally provided for in legislation as an exception to the relevant statuary power to search and seize. On Mr Kumar's specific queries pertaining to the operation of the privilege on police raids, I appreciate the point that clarity may be needed on how privileged documents can be protected and disputes over privilege resolved in such raids. But today's amendments do not touch on that procedure or operations. It is an issue that we will be looking at when we next review the CPC which will be soon. This should also answer Mr Lee's question on what we intend to do for such extra-curial privilege.

As for the abuse of privilege, the amendments provide very clearly that privilege does not prevent the disclosure of communications made in furtherance of illegal purposes or any fact observed by legal counsel which shows that a crime or fraud has been committed. Unless I have misunderstood Mr Kumar, he can clarify later. Also, anyone who conceals evidence not properly subject to privilege would be perverting the course of justice which under section 204A of the Penal Code is punishable up to seven years' imprisonment.

Page: 1143

On Mr Kumar's third issue concerning the scope of section 128A(4), he queried why the privilege for legal counsel is extended to companies and their related corporations but such benefit is not extended to limited liability partnerships and their related entities. These concerns have been raised by accounting firms who feel that they would be disadvantaged by the provisions. We are aware of the accounting firms' concerns. They have written to us. My Ministry is in touch with them. The current extension of privilege to related corporations in section 128(4) is a concession to corporate reality. Many MNCs operate under a group of related companies and the Companies Act has a definition of "related corporation". No similar definition exists in the Limited Liability Partnerships Act.

The suggestion is that there be a definition of direct or indirect ownership to be used to determine legitimate related entities of limited liability partnerships. That goes well beyond the scope of today's amendments and we felt that that needed more careful study. We need to be able to establish a clear nexus between the entity employing the legal counsel and the related entity claiming privilege, or run the risk that the provision will be abused to hide communications or material that should be rightly disclosed, be it for investigation, inspection or transparency. We would look carefully at the points made by the accounting profession and the points made by Mr Kumar, to see whether there need to be some amendments to the limited liability partnerships issue.

Mr Lee also raised a number of questions generally concerning the scope of the Evidence Act. He wanted to know what the legal professional advisor in section 131 included. Would it include advocates as well as in-house legal counsel? Will that mean communication with foreign lawyers is excluded from privilege? I would clarify that the main intention behind section 131 is to expand the definition of legal professional advisor to include in-house legal counsel and there is no intention to affect privilege or deal with privilege between foreign lawyers and their local clients. That remains to be dealt with by common law.

As regards Mr Lee's suggestion to adopt the Law Reform Committee's recommendation in their Report on Reforming Legal Professional Privilege to extend legal privilege to materials provided by third parties for the dominant purpose of seeking legal advice, we could look into this in the future. But any extension of privilege to third parties who are not lawyers or legal counsel needs to be dealt with carefully because of the prospect of abuse.

Lastly, on Mr Lee's suggestion to codify litigation privilege, there are presently no plans to do so but we can look into this.

Next, if I can move on to address the points raised by Mr Lee on expert opinion. Mr Lee does not take issue with the amendments but raised a number of suggestions relating to judicial training or dealing with biased expert witnesses and how they should be subject to sanctions. I think they relate primarily to how courts should deal with expert witnesses who come to court not so much as to assist the court but to advocate their clients' cases. That is improper. Again, thankfully, we have judges not juries who should be able to look at the witness and make a decision as to whether he is a true expert or an advocate for his client's case. There is some merit in looking at whether we should put in some rules on the issue of making the expert witness bear costs himself, but it is probably better dealt with by the courts. We will look at it with the courts and see what, if anything, ought to be done.

Page: 1144

On credit of rape victims in section 157(d), I think that is generally welcomed by all Members. What would happen as a result of the amendment is not that previous history would automatically be inadmissible but rather it is left to the courts to decide when it should be admissible. That depends on the issue of relevance. It is just that we should not legislatively provide that certain issues will be relevant.

Finally, on Mr Nair's comments regarding the issue of marital rape, I think that issue falls outside the purview of the present Bill as he himself recognised. That has got to be dealt with by the Ministry of Home Affairs. What I can say is when I was wearing that hat, the NGO "No to Rape" saw me as well. I found many of the arguments they put forward worth looking into. They made good points. I will certainly pass over Mr Nair's comments to the Ministry of Home Affairs.

Finally, Mrs Lina Chiam generally welcomed the amendments but her point was why has it taken since 2003, when the technology committee put forward its report on computer output evidence. I think the real point is that we have been slow about it, which is what she is seeking to make. There are a number of reports that are put forward by the Law Reform Committee as well as other committees. Some we took immediate action on. Then there are some like this on computer output. In 2003/2004, when the report was looked at, the prevailing view was the treatment or the requirement for computer evidence to be treated with extra caution and the greater number of requirements to show that it was properly produced was considered to be important. Over time, it has been reviewed a number of times by the Ministry together with the other stakeholders. We have sought to make the amendments and feel that now we are sufficiently confident with the usage and we do not need these extra safeguards. So, committees can come forward and put forward reports but we still have to apply our judgement to say, "Are we ready? Is it better to stick with the time-honoured approach to evidence and not change too quickly? Let us see how it operates in practice before we move." We also look at the practice of other jurisdictions and we have decided this is an appropriate time to move. Sir, I think I have covered all the questions.

Last of all, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to record my grave reservations about this aspect of the Bill.

Mr K Shanmugam : Taking Ms Lim's three questions, will I confirm that the effect of the amendments undo the decision in Lee's case? No, because the provision as amended would continue to give the court discretion at two levels. One, the threshold, whether it is to be admitted at all; and, two, whether once it is admitted, what weight is to be given.

Second question, would I agree that evidence of accomplices carries a higher risk? I would agree that, as a general principle, it carries a higher risk. And I emphasise general principle, which is why the court dealing with the issue on any specific case is better placed than Members of this House or myself to make general pronouncements.

And, third, does this Bill lower the bar of protection for the accused in criminal cases? What it does is it allows the court to consider relevant evidence. Ms Lim added on the phrase "it lowers the bar of protection" by allowing the irrelevant and unreliable evidence in. Absolutely not, unless we do not trust the judges. Because if it is irrelevant, as a matter of law, it is inadmissible. If it is unreliable, then it should not be admitted. By definition, the judge applies the law, irrelevant and unreliable evidence should not be in in the first place. What it does is this − bearing in mind the case law, that in some cases, most lawyers who are in practice will agree that hearsay evidence could be relevant. Should we have artificial rules which exclude it de facto upfront, without letting the courts have some discretion? That is the question. Ms Lim argues for that. I suggest that we should trust our judges and should let them decide on whether evidence is indeed reliable or unreliable. You can have compelling hearsay evidence, which the judge might want to look at and consider, and counsel will have the opportunity of addressing it. Let us not take an approach which is an all-or-nothing approach. It is the interests of justice that we are all looking at. There is much to comment on an approach where we clearly lay out that there is a framework within which the judge will consider, and he must ask himself whether the interests of justice require the admissibility of the evidence in the first place. And if it does, what weight will he ascribe to it. Those are my answers to the three questions.

Quite clearly, the purpose of this section is to deal with what the advocate and solicitor sees or hears after he has been engaged by his client. And if he should see or hear or know about the commission of any crime which was committed after his engagement, then clearly privilege does not apply.

The potential problem is that same language is now being employed for section 128(a) in relation to in-house counsel, and the term "employed" is also used. Let me give a scenario where some uncertainties will arise. Assuming a in-house legal counsel has been employed by a company, and he is there to give general advice. Should they go to the in-house counsel, under section 128(a), that communication may not be privilege. I think that is the difference, which I suspect, the Act is intended to cover. And that may well be the consequence of a plain reading of the proposed section. I hope I have clarified the positions.

Mr Hri Kumar Nair : I understand that. And if advice was sought in those circumstances, that would in any event, in our view, would be covered by privilege, and, if clarification is needed, we will make sure it is clarified.

Transplant Applications after Latest Amendment to Human Organ Transplant Act (HOTA)

16 Ms Ellen Lee asked the Minister for Health (a) how many applications have been received by the Transplant Ethics Committee (TEC) since the last amendment to the Human Organ Transplant Act took effect two years ago; (b) what is the breakdown of these applications in terms of (i) Singaporeans, Permanent Residents and foreigners; (ii) the number of approved and rejected applications in each category; (iii) the reasons for the rejected cases; (iv) the income profile of the donors and donees in each of the categories in (i); and (c) whether the applications cause concern among TEC members that only more affluent patients could afford the necessary transplants.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : Since the last amendment to the Human Organ Transplant Act on 1st November 2009, Transplant Ethics Committees (TECs) have received 325 applications for living donor organ transplants. Twenty-six percent of the applications were made by Singaporeans and Permanent Residents (PRs), with the remaining applications by foreigners.

The TEC gives written authorisation for the living donation when it is satisfied that the donor has given his consent freely, without inducement or duress, and that the donation is ethical. All TEC members in each case must unanimously agree to approve the organ donation before authorisation is given. Each member will exercise his or her judgement in each case, taking into consideration many factors. As such, the TECs are not required to provide the reasons for their decisions. Four percent of the applications by Singaporeans and PRs and 9% of the applications by foreigners were not approved.

The donors and recipients are from a diverse group ranging from high income professionals to those with no income such as housewives and retired persons. For cases involving unrelated locals where they have declared an income, the median monthly income for donor and recipient is $1,900 and $2,250 respectively. For foreigners, as donors and recipients may come from different countries, income comparison may not be meaningful. They range from $0 to $300,000.

We have not received any feedback from the TEC members on affordability concerns. However, my Ministry will continue to ensure access to healthcare services, including transplants for Singaporeans. Singaporeans and PRs are also eligible for Government subsidies for the surgery, hospitalisation and immunosuppressant medications.

Needy Singaporean recipients who cannot afford to pay for their donors' surgical bills and long-term follow-up can receive further assistance from special programmes set up by Voluntary Welfare Organisations (VWOs), such as the "Share a Life" programme, jointly launched in 2005 by the Kidney Dialysis Foundation (KDF) and the Khoo Foundation, and the "Live Donor Support Fund" established in 2009 by the National Kidney Foundation (NKF). These various schemes and our Government subsidies continue to ensure that no Singaporean would be denied medical treatment due to financial difficulties.
